From the outside you only get to tour around half the building when you are in (ground and first floor). A couple of sparse rooms to visit. Not a lot of information provided when you are inside.

If you come from a new world country where the oldest buildings are perhaps only a hundred years old then you might be impressed otherwise once inside you are faced with a quad so seeing the same view from 4 different sides of the building, go downstairs, see the same, then exit. Take a look at the pictures on line and take a view whether seeing it in real life is worth the 18 euros.

title: When you see long stressful lines, look for other ways to experience that 'must-do' thing
text: I'm sure you've read about the looooong line for ticket holders to enter this landmark, and when you get there, your brain has a hard time processing why you even picked an entrance time and prebooked. There was NO way I was spending hours in a hot line of folks with the sun beaming down on me, so I skipped it and entered the church next door instead b/c that line was way shorter and not even sure you needed a ticket to do this! It's where Vasco Da Gama is laid to rest, and the scene is rather moving. With Belem Tower being closed for renovation (sorry folks scaffolding all around the bottom) I guess the monastery is overrun? Next stop, steps away from the church is the famous bakery making the pastel de nata treat and you'll know you're there b/c there are swarms of people waiting in, that's right, another line. But on the side of the building there's a to-go line with like 2 people waiting where you can get the very same thing. All I did was get 2 pastries and a Coke Zero to-go and with my receipt, I flashed it to the hostess who allowed me to enter for the restroom (huge & nice) and I snapped a photo of the inside and left. Ate my treats on a shady park bench across the street. One more tip for your trip out to Belem, to get on the train or to get across the train lines to the other side, you're looking for either an underground walkway basically like entering the NYC subway or a skywalk near an office building...tons of people looked very confused about this. I heard you could go to the top of the statue with all the explorers on it but it looked too scary for me. Have fun!

title: 18 euros a shame ...
text: What a disappointment... 1 hour waiting in full sun, 18 euros per person for a visit (even if magnificent) so short!!! No visit to the gardens... A shame...

title: No line-cutting! Endless waiting!!!
text: There's no way back! Tickets purchased online do not give access to a skip-the-line queue simply because it does not exist! There is only one line and you have to wait an hour to two hours in full sun. Scam. We can't wait with young children. The sale of excessive tickets continues, it‚Äôs sad!

title: Not worth it üëéüèº
text:
The waiting time (1h30 in full sun) harassed by vendors in the saddle, is not worth the little visit.
The cloister is certainly beautiful but not worth this wait especially with tickets taken in advance! And in addition we have to wait another time to visit the church.
Between the price, the waiting etc this monastery is very pretty from the outside!
Run away!

title: Don't bother. Long queue. Little to see.
text: After a 30 minute tram ride and an hour and a half in the queue, the short visit to the cloisters just didn't cut it. Yes they are nice cloisters and have a long history, but apart from two empty rooms, that's all you see. Watching people leave they all looked distinctly underwhelmed. The number of visitors inside is limited at any one time, hence the long wait to get in. However on the day we visited they could have let everyone in the queue inside at once and it would have been less crowded than most historical sites. I suspect if it was free immediate entry, no one would bother. There are many better places in Lisbon to spend your time.

title: To flee
text:
2 hours of queuing in full sun with tickets purchased in advance!!!! The site is far from worth it!!! And you have to start again to visit the church.
To flee!!!

title: Disappointed
text: 45‚Äô waiting, just for the square. Price should include the church also. Not much explanation. Nice to see but felt like a waste of time. There are better places to go to

title: Don't bother
text:
Just a gigantic waste of time, not worth the entry fee at all. You can queue up and enter the church for free - do that, it's worth it.

But don't queue in the hot sun nor pay the extortionate entry fee's to wander around two small floors of this Monastry.

We were there for such little time we genuinely thought we'd taken a wrong turn when we ended up at the exit.

title: Terrible‚Ä¶wait is unbearable for a 10 minute walk-through
text: Terrible‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt let the other reviews for you. We had tickets for 10:30 and was told to be there 30 minutes prior, which we did. 2 to 3 hours, ya if you consider waiting over two hours outside and the beating sun when no place to sit. Just to go inside and do pillars and nice architecture for a 10 minute walk. There are much nicer places to see in Lisbon.

title: Not worth it
text: Like many other I was horrified by the queue. , the main problem being the large tour groups who got in at the expense of the individual travellers. Whilst the carvings are beautiful there really is not much to see and you then have to queue again for the church. No where to sit and no shade from the sun in the queue. I would not recommend it.

title: Excessive waiting time
text: We didn‚Äôt see the monument because when we arrived at 10:30, half an hour after they opened the waiting time in the queue it was about 3 hours. Even though we had the tickets bought we had to wait. I think they should indicate that on their website, in most monuments buying tickets in advance makes the wait reasonable and everything is organized. They should also indicate that the minimum you have to wait is two hours, do not indicate on a sign that time when you pass through the door.

title: Long lines, only two time slots, no benches, no water and no washrooms nearby. If you have a disability forget it
text: Travelling with my family I was so disappointed. We arrived in the afternoon. The lines were so long. You had to line up for tickets and then join a outrageously long line. It was so disorganized. We came from Ontario, Canada. My daughter has a rare disability and bladder condition. I couldn't have her standing in line forever with no toilet in site. There were no benches for order people to sit while waiting. It was beaming hot. We just walked away. I was so disappointed as it was the one site that I wanted to see while in Lisbon. My husband and I are both 65 and can't stand for hours. Why not book specific time slots? We were able to do this when we visited Sintra. Having only 2 time slots is not sufficient. Subjecting the elderly and individuals to long waits, without washroom facilities, benches or water close by does not take the tourist's experience into consideration.

title: Not worth the time or money
text: Our tickets were for 10:00 but we didn‚Äôt get admitted until after 11. The stone carving is beautiful but that is all there is to see, really. You can buy an audio tour but that isn‚Äôt included in the admission fee

title: Bad trip
text: On arrival at the opening, even with an online ticket, there is an hour and a half wait for entry. Inside, another half an hour to use the ladies' toilet. The ticket is 18 euros, the level of service is very poor.

title: Very disappointing
text: Very, very disappointing. 1 hour and a half in a row in the rain with no priority for online tickets. Once you enter the bathrooms far away, few and tiny. Of a huge building you see a small part. But the most absurd thing is that after seeing the cloister they let you out in the rain to queue up again to enter the church. Terrible organization. In Barcelona to the sagrada familia with the online ticket you enter at the appointed time and have the guide via free app. So much artistic beauty wasted

title: If you like endless queues!
text:
I put this note in very disappointed of the endless waiting time to access the monastery (almost 3 hours on the day of our visit).
Included in the Lisboa Card

title: Scam Attraction; Visit to Waste Time
text:
[TOURISTS PAY ATTENTION] This is a tourist trap; While the Monestaty is pretty, it‚Äôs not worth the ticket prices.
1. The line to get into the monastery is extremely disorganized. Even though we had tickets prior to arriving it took 2.5 hours to get into a monetary, which was NOT during busy season.
2. There is literally NOTHING within the monetary. No exhibits, no seating, no signs or guidance. Beware if you‚Äôre traveling with kids and elderly.
3. This is a scam, as noted above. There is a separate enterance for the ‚Äúchurch‚Äù. The church is free of charge (which they don‚Äôt advertise) yet if you have tickets to the monetary, you have to wait in a separate like to get into the church. Common sense would simply be to let the people who purchased tickets into the church as well after waiting hours to get into the monetary.
4. There‚Äôs a LOT of panhandlers harassing you while you‚Äôre in line to the monetary. Beware of pickpocket‚Äôs and ticket scams.

I do not recommend this attraction. The hassle with tickets and simply getting into the monastery was not worth it. Especially when there‚Äôs nothing to see in the Monastery other than the architecture.

title: Very bad and unprofessional service in ticket office
text:
We tried to visit the Monastery today. We arrived at the ticket office where we were advised that there is a 2 hrs queue to get inside the Monastery. We asked what is the waiting time to enter the church (next to the Monastery) and we were told is about 20‚Äô. We specifically told to the lady who was issuing the tickets that we will go only to the church and she said it is 18 euro per person (we were 4 so the total amount was 72 euro)
Once we entered the church we noticed that no one checked the tickets in the entrance so we were a bit sceptical about the fees. Following our visit, we asked the security at the entrance and he said the church visit is for free. Within 20‚Äô after we have purchased the tickets we went back to the ticket office and explained to the lady that there was a misunderstanding and since we have not used the tickets to enter the Monastery we wanted a refund. She said is not possible and that all the info is available for someone to read and denied her mistake. The whole point is that the ladies in the tickets office speak very poor English and are completely unprofessional. Since this site is visited by thousands of people everyday, the stuff should be in a position to interact with the visitors using professional English in order to avoid similar issues. We are quite sure she did not understand our discussion and got lost in translation. As a minimum, they could have at least refunded the entrance fees.

title: That's bad!
text: So where do we start? The monastery highly recommend it because very nice, the cloister for me failed. Or rather rejected the organization. The cloister is suggestive and reminded me a bit of the style of the English cloisters, but let‚Äôs say that for what you see the ticket price is definitely high. In addition, I had read that there was a lot of queue and so I had bought tickets online in advance, it was no use! Unlike other places that had separate lines (those who already had a ticket had some sort of priority) we did more than an hour in a row under the sun. I had booked my ticket for 11 and we went in at 12.15. In hindsight I would only visit the monastery.

title: Long queue for a short and useless visit
text: There was a long queue and the visit was so short. There are not scheduled visits, no places to seat and enjoy the monastery. I do not recommend it.

title: Ridiculously long queues from early on. Don‚Äôt bother unless you like standing around for hours.
text: Following advice online we arrived here no more than 30min after opening time. There must have been at least 500 people in the queue to get in. We had a Lisbon Card which allegedly means you can skip the queue. This is not at all true. The only thing you done have to do is go to the ticket office first. You still have to join the hundreds of people in the line, many of whom are on tours from the many coaches which are parked up there. Having seen the size of the queue, we decided against spending hours waiting in the blazing sunshine and took the bus back into the city.

title: Extremely disappointing and too expensive!
text: Extremely long wait about 1h30 in the rain, bad organization and unpleasant staff , the architectures are very beautiful, but 18‚Ç¨ to only see the cloister... It's way too expensive.

title: Very poorly organised
text: Very poorly organized. We waited in line for an hour to finally realize that we had to buy tickets across the road in a park. How can you imagine when you're in line at the other end of the building that you have to buy tickets somewhere else? Extremely disappointed because we had to give up.

title: Do not book in advance!
text:
We had booked in advance: bad took us! Arrived at 11 am, an hour after the opening, the tail was already 500m and the regulator announced two hours of waiting (in the rain and in the wind)
As long as there is no regulation with time-stamped tickets, the museum administration will be in its pockets selling tickets that cannot be honored by a visit...
Only solution: arrive at 9am, one hour before the opening...

title: Awful experience for older visitors
text: Bought tickets online in advice but still had to wait in a line for 45 minutes to get in. No seating outside and no sitting inside. The 30 minute visit was not worth the wait. And the toilets were filthy. On exiting, had to join another line to go into the adjacent church. All the seats were railed off there as well.

title: Disappointing visit
text:
You think, I bought tickets online for ‚Ç¨19,- to get in faster, but that's a wrong assumption. You just have to stand in the (long) queue (we 40 min.).
Once inside you can walk 2 x a monastery tour and after half an hour you are outside again....
We expected much more from this visit. Where's the rest of the monastery? And almost nowhere were there signs with explanations.
This really wasn't worth the visit. It's too bad. And the price is way too much at ‚Ç¨19,- pp. You should go to another museum or location.

title: Want your money but don't care what experience you have
text: This attraction is badly managed and poorly signposted with visitors frequently getting to the front of the queue to find they needed to queue for tickets first at the kiosk in the park area. Visitors are encouraged to buy tickets online but it is virtually impossible due to a lack of signal. We were charged full price to find that only the cloister is open, the rest is closed for renovations. We also paid extra for the commentary which was very poor and kept cutting out. I recommend the Carmo Convent instead

title: Don't bother - Half the attraction for the full price.
text:
The ticket office is on the opposite side of the road to the monastery & church. 18‚Ç¨ each. BUT, it's only when you have presented your tickets and get into the building that it says the church is currently closed for restoration. You're not told this at the ticket office and there's no reduction in the price - shocking! The two storey cloisters are certainly quite ornate but when you've seen one you seen them both. There were no "interpretation boards" to explain what it's all about. In and out in about 30 minutes and much of that was trying to find the womens' loos. They are not signposted (come in, go right at the bottom of the stair case, then left and left again).
The gents are on the first floor and a little easier to find.
Hardly an "attraction"

title: Unrewarding
text: Not really worth it. Paid over 50 Eur as a family and there was nothing to see except the cloister. After a maximum of 30 minutes you are out. Church was closed for construction work

title: Don‚Äôt Bother!
text: What a waste of time and money. Big line and big price for this attraction. Yet, once you get in, there‚Äôs literally nothing to see. We were done in 20 minutes. And the adjacent church was closed for renovation. Don‚Äôt do it!!!

title: If you have plenty of time...
text: If you have to wait to buy tickets or wait to enter, I would suggest you give it a miss. You only get to see one cloister and a dining hall in exchange for a very long wait time. If you have a Lisboa Card you are not guaranteed preferred entry and may have to join the regular queue, so consider that. Most of the huge site is not for public display. A visit to Mosteiro de Sao Vincente Fora was much better and with the Lisboa Card cost 6 euro, well worth the money. Go there instead if you have limited time.

title: Worth it only very limited
text:
Far too expensive, totally overrated

An extremely long queue, a 2-storey cloister with admittedly very beautiful stonework. Nevertheless, it is not worth the wait and the entrance fee.

title: Waste of money
text:
The exterior of the monastery is beautiful
After paying 18 euros, they saw only the patio of the monastery.
Not worth that kind of money.
It took 10 minutes.

title: Too expensive
text: A scam. They charge 18‚Ç¨ to enter and all you see is the cloister, there is nothing else. It is nice but not for that price, I would charge an entrance fee of 5‚Ç¨ and it is more than enough.

title: Overpriced
text: It's beautiful cloister but definitely not worth 18 euro per person to visit u will be in and out in 20 mins max nothing else to see , save your money and just visit church for free üòäüëç

title: not good value
text: Great history and beautiful architecture but the price is a lot for 30 mins looking g af 1 courtyard! The monastary at monastery of Sao Vicente de Fora is stunning and well worth a look.

title: BEWARE OF THE GUARDS TELLING THAT YOUR TICKET FOR A TOUR IS INVALID
text:
We purchased a tour from Cool Tours agency and promptly waited for the tour guide to come. Since it was early I asked one of the guards if I am in the right line for the tour group. He looked at my QR code and he said "Your ticket is invalid and you have been scammed, I suggest that you scan the code here and buy real tickets. There are no guided tours here nor any tour guides from agencies operating". After hearing this we bought the ticket in the QR code in the line and paid for it since we dont want to be incovenienced. That‚Äôs when someone from the tour group line shouted my name for a guided tour! I just said "I was just told by that person that you are a scam and you don‚Äôt exist!" The tour guide called the Portuguese Heritage Admin to complain. A lady who were suppose to be in authority talked to us and didnt even apologized and protected the guard that there might be misunderstanding on our part regarding tickets. She even told me to not take a photo nor look at that person. She just refrerred us to a bureaucratic QR code again to process our refund that heaven knows if it will be processed or not.

I was told that this is a regular occurrence in this attraction because they discriminate people who are not Portuguese, tour agencies and just lets tourists buy double tickets as retribution for not going through direct tickets. I suggest that the authorities of the Portuguese Tourism put a stop on this scheme or everybody should be informed on the types of tickets that they accept.

Anyways our tour guide is very knowleageable and very considerate, it‚Äôs just that the wrong information of the guard put us off an otherwise beautiful adventure.

title: Cloisters overpriced and over rated.
text:
Ticket office for the cloisters is 100 metres from the entrance so check the que length before buying the 18 euros per person ticket (9 euros if youre over 65).
We visited on a Sunday and the cathedral was closed for visitors and there was no que for the cloisters.
Inside the cloisters there's very little to see except the architecture, a couple of tombs and before you know it, youre back at the place you entered thinking 'is that it, did we miss something ?'. It looks like a massive spectacular building fom the outside and the ticket office posters give the impression of a grande tour but in the end its not.
Maybe the cathedral is worth seeing and thats free when its open, the cloisters however is overpriced and over rated.

title: Total Nepo
text: The monastery is completely overrated. One can reach the ground floor and the 1. View floor around the courtyard - for 18 euros per person! That's all there is! Portuguese people come in for free, by the way. The church next to it is free.

title: A disappointment
text: With online tickets taken on the official website, paid 18 euros each, we did not enter because of the long queue, it would have taken at least 120 minutes to wait.

title: Beware of tickets (even when bought directly from them)
text: Timed tickets are a farce. We waited for over two hours just to get in. They had sold tickets for a day when the monument wasn't even open, and when we asked, we were told to line up. Just in case, we asked the guard and she checked the tickets for us (it was a good idea cause the tickets were void). The staff has a terrible attitude overall, and while the place is beautiful, the staff's horrible attitude ruins it all.

title: Full price, mileage queue and ...closed.for restoration
text: Endless queue also for ticket holders purchased online on the official website. The visit is limited to the cloister (so it has a much shorter duration and you lose much of the charm of the place). The rest of the structure is under restoration, too bad that this information is not indicated on the site. Don't waste time or money...

title: Closed and unannounced
text: We bought tickets in advance, as many other people who stayed out as we did. If they want to give the day off is fine, but if they sold tickets, they had no difficulty warning (because they had the mails) so that people from all over the world would not arrive. Clearly they're worth tourism

title: Not worth it.
text: Meh. I don‚Äôt recommend paying to go see the cloisters. No information and not much to see. Yes, the courtyard is beautiful but there really isn‚Äôt much else (unless you are an architect). We were in and out in 10 minutes. The church is free so save your euros and go see that.

title: Just a box to tick
text: You buy a time slot and they keep you waiting ages while they let all the just arrived tour groups in ahead of you. Not much info.

title: Lovely monastery, but the church closed without warning.
text: The Monastery is excellent, particularly the cloister. The church was closed without warning so we couldn't visit it.

title: In short:
text: It is not worth the cost of admission, 12 euros. Inside there is not much to see, a visit that lasts up to 15 min. Beautiful from the outside, inside nothing big. I wouldn't go back, or rather I wouldn't spend to get in

title: Very disappointing indeed !
text:
Beware their website says that they are open on Mondays !
IT IS CLOSED ON MONDAYS
Very disappointing indeed !
This also applies to the Belem Tower, very irritating !

title: Disappointing waste of time
text: This was the most (and only) disappointing site we visited during our 10 days in Portugal. The online booking process is challenging and we never received the email with our tickets (which was its own drama on-site, we ended up buying 2 more tickets). Most importantly, the ‚Äútimed entry‚Äù selections are a joke- no matter what time you arrive, everyone stands in the same gigantic line to enter. Today the wait was 1.5-2hrs. We had heard such wonderful things about the Monastery but no one mentions the visit takes about 10mins max- walk around the stunning arched Cloister, go into 2 empty rooms with beautiful gothic arched ceilings, and that‚Äôs it. So, almost 2hr wait with a timed entry ticket for 15mins of actual touring. No brochure, guided tours or audio guide to try to bring what you‚Äôre seeing to life. The Castelo Sao Jorge was infinitely more interesting, be sure to take the guided tours of the museum and archaeological sites. The Lisbon Cathedral also has a small but interesting museum upstairs in addition to the beautiful church itself.

title: Avoid unless you have lots of time on your hand
text:
Please don't waste your money on visiting this place. It looks perfect to spend a half day or so but the fact is this Mosteiro is NOT set up for tourists.
4 of us spent over 60 Euros and booked a time slot the day before we visited at 10.30am.
When we arrived it all looked beautiful and that's where it ended.
On approaching the building and I'm not exaggerating, the queue outside was at least a quarter of a mile long. Hundreds & hundreds of people waiting to get in.
Ah well it was a good thing we booked & paid for our time slot the day before and felt sorry for all these people waiting in the queue.
We walked to the front of the queue and spoke to the official explaining we had booked & paid & had our time slot as evidenced on our phones.who said that the time slots did not matter and we would have to go to the back of the queue. WHAT!!!
After some banter, it was clear we were NOT getting in.
Apparently they let some 300 people in every half hour and since we were now at the back of the queue, we estimated this would mean at least 1.5 hours standing in a queue YES, at least or perhaps longer.
Could things get any worse? YES, after 25 minutes waiting in the queue which didn't move in that time, it started to rain. Right, that's it, we had all had enough & moved on.
This place is clearly NOT set up for the amount of tourists who visit.
The website is misleading with time slots etc.
One other thing which we considered after we had left was that it must have been gridlock when people were inside this building.
Hope this help others from wasting a morning.

title: Don't waste time trying to visit...there are better ways to spend your time in Lisbon
text: We bought timed tickets on line, arrived in our allocated time slot, and found there is no separate queue for those who have taken the trouble to book timed tickets. The place is overwhelmed by coachloads of predominantly cruise ship passengers who are ruining the experience for everyone else. The line was several hundred yards long, and scarcely moved in the first 20 minutes we were in it. It was clearly going to take most of the morning just to get in, so we gave up and went to other nearby museums. It's a disgrace that the Patrimonio Cultural responsible for the Mosteiro can't get their act together to organise a proper ticketing/queuing system

title: Very expensive and with queues for what you can visit
text: Queues over an hour despite having tickets. You only visit the cloister, which is huge, but contains nothing, a disappointment. We Spaniards have many cloisters and ecclesiastical art much better, without so many queues and at better prices. The tomb of Vasco de Gama is located in the attached church which is freely accessible.

title: Do not do if there is queue
text: The two hours of queuing under the sun in a row is not worth the visit. Is complete non-organization the expression of Portugal?

title: Total mismanagement
text:
Your timed, pre purchased ticket is useless as there are a thousand people waiting in line with your time
Or earlier. There is no control whatsoever- if you want to see a bunch of other tourists, buy a ticket- if you want to see a beautiful monument don‚Äôt bother - all you see are other people.

title: Not worth the wait or the price
text: No sorry. Not worth the wait or the price. All you see is the cloister which is empty. The confessionals are closed off, there is no chapter house. It is separate from the church itself. Absolutely not worth the wait. If you desperately want to go, come close to the last entry time, it only takes about 15-20 minutes to walk around it.

title: Beautiful but not worth the hassle.
text: We had the first timed entry ticket of the day but still waited an hour to get in while hundreds of cruise ship tour group went in (Cruise ships seem to ruin everything). Once inside it is very beautiful but there is no signage to explain the history of what you are seeing. There were no Audio guides either. Not sure it‚Äôs worth the time investment. The line for the Church was long but moved at a good pace. You will also be constantly harassed by people selling hats, scarves etc. Go to Monastery Vincente da Fora.

title: Falta total de respeito no tratamento ao turista e clinte!
text:
My experience at Jeronimos Monastery with your partner Headout was extremely unpleasant. We bought the tickets on line in advance in order to avoid long lines, and at the end of the day it was useless.

In the email we received with the booking confirmation, we were informed that the booking time was 10:00 AM, and we were required to get there 15 minutes in advance. We followed the instructions and arrived there at 9:35 AM and for our surprise there was only a huge entrance line, where all visitors with tickets should wait. When we inquired why we have to stay in line as we have already booked the tickets, the answer we received form the security person was that we had to stay in the line and wait to get in. We inquired about the tickets booked, and she had no clue and there was nobody there to provide any information, except a security guard!

This is complete unacceptable. Clients and turists in this case deserve to be respected and to be provided with accurate information about the conditions of the tickets bought.

title: No!!!!
text:
Almost as beautiful from the outside.
Save your time and money for other things...
12 euros is robbery!!!

title: Beautiful, but not worth the experience
text:
Amazing architecture, terrible tourist experience, especially if you're a woman.

Even with a timed ticket, even if you arrive early, you will have to queue for over an hour in the blazing sun. No seats, no shade.

Naturally, you'll drink lots of water to stay hydrated, but when inside the men's toilets are right by the entrance - the women's are a whole floor away through the exit! Only three cubicles for hundreds of women visiting, so be prepared to queue again!

It is cooler inside the monastery, but still nowhere to sit, all the benches inside have signs telling you not to sit.

The architecture is beautiful, but it's hard to enjoy with heat exhaustion! In my opinion, really, really not worth it.

title: No monument is worth an hour in a row under the sun
text: You book your ticket for a certain time. Some times are sold out. So you think there's a real contingency. You arrive and find an apocalyptic line. At least an hour in the sun with those who want to sell water, glasses and sanctuary-style hats. No monument is worth such a sacrifice. Don't go there.

title: Visit of Belem
text:
Two hours of queuing for this frankly is not worth it.
The architecture is beautiful , the places are clean.
No explanation, no audio guide.
And after 20 minutes we go out and we have to queue again to visit the church.

title: I wish that I could give zero stars
text:
The Monastery is fabulous
This score is for the treatment that we received this morning.
We were booked with a superb local company, and began on the first floor of the Monastery. This took around 40 minutes.
When we came downstairs, a very aggressive male security officer ambushed our fabulous guide. He said that we had been too long and would have limited access to.the lower floor.
I worked in secure psychiatry, I have rarely seen such aggression. The security officer was much bigger than our guide, and got well within the normal body space.
The security officer then called for another officer, and then two police officers.
Our guide was firm, but dignified and polite, even when his phone was taken off him and examined.
Our group was escorted from the Monastery by the police. Just incredible. We were all from big British, Canadian and American cities, takes a lot to shock.
I have no idea if there is a time limit, but this was dreadful behaviour and should be investigated.

title: Long queues and expensive
text: Very long queue for the tickets and then the church. Expensive tickets to then be charged EXTRA for the sacristy! Cloister was good.

title: It's not worth it
text: A lack of respect with the vacationer, we bought the ticket in advance on the internet with a scheduled time, we stay 2 hs in line, in the sun, when we enter there is nothing too much, do not indicate the visit, loss of time and money, if you like to stay in line make the visit.

title: Catastrophic
text: Catastrophic organization. No queue depending on the slot booked. An hour's line in the sun. Arrived inside, impossible to sit. I don't recommend visiting.

title: Not worth the wait
text: We waited 1.5 hours in the brutal sun, with no shade, outside the monastery that took us about 20 minutes to go through. Ambulances had to be called because of people passing out in line. Once inside, there was plenty of space -- easily at least half of the people waiting in line could have been let in with no issue. The security guards and people working the attraction were rude -- they would rush you along (once you were inside) if you were standing for what they deemed to be too long. Yet they had no problem letting you stand in the sun for over an hour. The inside was lovely, but beyond the courtyard there was not much to see. I would skip this attraction, especially during the busy season.

title: A real shame
text: A real shame, after waiting more than 2 hours in the sun, one of the 8 tickets that we bought by Headout, and that arrived in the same mail, we were told at the entrance that it had been used 2 days earlier, in the morning, as soon as we had bought them in the afternoon and on top of that we were not even in Lisbon. They would not let us all in, seeing in the evidence that it was their mistake and the tourist portal, the solution; buy a new ticket and if you want to claim for the wrong one. A REAL SHAME!!!! They should have a plan for these cases, which the workers confirmed happens often, and that the client did not pay the duck, such as generating an auxiliary ticket and claiming them to the tourist portal for the one issued twice. REGRETTABLE. Wherever I go I will not advise this monument or the tourist portals these that take advantage of people.

title: The monastery??
text: Aiutooooooo.... Arrived in Belem we made the ticket 12 ‚Ç¨ tried to do it online on the spot, but the line flowed fast enough and we did it there... moreover very deceptive because we believed that the ticket included 3 other attractions and only later we realized that it was just the ticket for the monastery.... we headed to the entrance, but the line to enter was very long.... 2 hours of waiting under the thick sun and then enter and turn it was enough half an hour .. From the outside it is huge and beautiful, but the inside since they make you visit only the cloister has nothing more than the cloisters of the cathedrals that you can find around and for free. Would I recommend it? Even no it's more beautiful from the outside than from the inside

title: Disappointed
text: Only the cloister is visited. Other places were visited years ago. Two hours of queuing in the sun, even if you have paid admission and with entrance hours. For the visit, another 20-minute queue. I do not discount the historical and architectural value

title: Poor organization
text: Beautiful cloister but bad organization. Despite the skip-the-line ticket bought online on the official site with indicative time, we did two hours in a row under the sun. Once we visited the cloister we could not see the church because we had to make another line just as long.

title: Unfortunate tourist admission
text: Terrible queues to enter having the entrance with schedule. Unheard of today, you lousy organization. No more shadows or seats, 1:30 h queue. Dire

title: Ridiculous organization
text: Ticket bought online, then you arrive on site and the line for visitors with ticket is KILOMETRIC, under the scorching sun, prey to illegal sellers of water, caps, umbrellas and bracelets. Incomprehensible the non-quota in time slots. Or rather, understandable when you think that tickets, once purchased, are not refundable. Bad experience and zero respect for tourists and visitors.

title: Poor reception of tourists
text: TO ENTER THE CHURCH YOU DO NOT NEED A TICKET but nobody says it, leaving the information to questionable interpretations of the bad signage. Everyone complains (and we are talking about thousands of people a day) clashing with very rude staff. The site ‚Äì a serious problem for all Portuguese monuments ‚Äì does not work or goes on cumbersomely. You have to queue at the box office, then queue to enter the church and then queue third to enter the cloister and monastery, all under the scorching sun. It would be enough to allow entry to the church to those who bought the ticket after visiting the cloister, thus unifying the line to avoid all these people one of the worst tourist experiences of all time.

title: Deplorable organisation
text:
Sale of tickets with a time slot that does not correspond to anything, you have to queue in full sun for more than an hour!!!
Thank you the management of the monastery and moreover the staff at the entrance speaks only Portuguese so for the explanations ...
Do not book, the line for the ticket office is short and you can decide according to the conditions of access to the monastery

title: Poor organization
text: Very bad information about access and/or the possibility of changing dates following the strike on 15 August 2024. Discomfort for queue of 1 hour and a half under the sun and then not being able to enter.

title: A bad experience
text:
A catastrophic organization, a wait of more than an hour in direct sunlight, an unsympathetic and not attentive staff.
Curiously, when we (finally) manage to get back, there are few people inside. A real joke.

title: Expensive and tail in the sun
text: Very nice cloister, definitely to see... in pictures. We are a family of 3 and paid 30‚Ç¨ to see 10 minutes of a cloister that, as beautiful as it is, is not worth the expense and not even the hours of queueing for the entrance.

title: Bad organization
text: Bad organization. Purchased tickets online with choice of time. No respect of 'time but you enter only after doing 1 hour and a half in a row under the sun. Obscene organization. The photo shows only half the row

title: Buying tickets online doesn't guarantee it's open
text: I bought tickets online for entry later the same day from the official ticket site. When I got to the monastery it was closed due to a strike. It was a wasted three hour round trip on a very hot day. A simple sorry would I made things better, but that was too much for the staff who lacked any basic empathy.

title: Disappointed
text: Lousy organization. Two and a half hours waiting in a queue, no information whatsoever. At very high temperatures, elderly people, children, no shade, no water... the price in advance of 12 individual euros... no one knows what time you will access! In the end you visit in a quarter of an hour, the cloister and little else. To see the church a new queue and again the same!

title: Total fraud and scam
text: Disappointing. A scam. We pay 12 euros per person per ticket by purchasing it two weeks in advance and with check-in time at 10.30. When we arrived it turned out that no matter whether you had the entrance or not, you had to queue huge that went around the monument. Two hours of waiting in the sun. When we enter it turns out that you only have access to see the cloister and nothing else (10 min visit). To see the church you have to go out and queue again. A disgrace. Not worth it at all, cheating, scamming, total scamming.

title: Disappointed, it's a real scam
text: We buy tickets two weeks in advance, with check-in time at 10:30. When we arrived, we had a single infinite queue, and an expected wait of 2 hours. After two long hours of waiting in the sun, we managed to enter, and see the cloister and two empty halls that we saw in just 15 minutes. When I asked to see the church, I was informed that another queue had to be queued. Disappointing, it's a scam, lack of organization, lack of empathy, not worth it.

title: 2h queue for 15/20 minutes visit
text: The best Attraction in the city if you like to queue in full sun... you bought your tickets in advance time stamped passing to enjoy a skip the line?? What nenni! Queue like everyone else ... the timetable on the ticket is strictly pointless!!Certainly the building is beautiful the cloister is very beautiful but there is only that to contemplate... that and 2 large rooms, one with a tomb and the other it was a large refectory ... To say that it is essential maybe if you have time to waste and if you want to enjoy the Lisbon sun in your face. And also take advantage during this waiting loooongue to be alpaulated by the many itinerant merchants who offer you their hardware without attacking you certainly but very insistent. And yes 2 hours to kill you will see them pass and iron... in short do as you want but frankly at 12‚Ç¨ entry it is expensive the minute of visit but super profitable in waiting time!!

title: Bad Attraction, treat visitors like cattle
text: More than 2 hours in line in the sun, even with scheduled hours. There's no place to sit in the monastery. Badly educated staff and stressed by the stress of visitors who already arrive annoyed by the ridiculous waiting. Why not arrange the ticket time??? Besides the monastery inside is beautiful, but nothing spectacular. I don't recommend visiting unless you like being mistreated

title: Beautiful place but catastrophic organization
text:
The place is beautiful but the organization is catastrophic. Despite the tickets taken in advance for a specific time (on the 1st morning) we waited more than an hour to return.
Only the cloister can be visited. Then to visit the church you have to queue again. We've given up.
Yet the place is splendid

title: Do not buy tickets in high season
text: Offering tickets without limiting tickets per time slot leads to a situation that is difficult to accept: more than 2 hours waiting, standing in the sun! We could not make this visit and we are not the only ones to have given up!!

title: Visit ruined by too many linesü§î
text:
We bought tickets online and yet we had to queue for 1 hour and a half under the sun.... and the tickets were non-refundable. The only "service" was the illegal sale of water and scarves to protect themselves from the sun. Finally entered the monastery has a beautiful cloister but unfortunately little else to visit... for the church there was another row... impossible.
Too bad because in front of the monastery there was a well-kept garden that perhaps could be used for waiting.

title: Outrageous organisation
text: The organization is shameful. After a line of one hour when we had tickets, we visit the monastery and leaving we want to visit the church at 12 o'clock but it is closed because there is a wedding. We return at 3pm, as requested and after waiting 1h30 in full sun with the children, we are told that the church will not reopen. Shame!

title: Endless wait for an express visit üëé
text:
1h30 waiting under a blazing sun to visit only the cloister, despite buying a time-stamped ticket ü§∑‚Äç‚ÄôÔ∏è
no bench either in line or inside
Staff with unkind entrance
The highlight: to visit the church you have to wait again in a line about as long as that for the cloister...
Horrible experience. I strongly discourage until access is improved

title: Hieronymites in August
text:
So disappointed

By 9:00 a.m. on site, there was already an endless queue. So I decided to take tickets on the internet by booking the 11am slot, time to visit belem and the monument of discovery. We arrive at 11am the queue is even bigger and I look for the place to enter with my Reservation....well in fact there are none, the Reservation is useless because it does not avoid the long wait in full sun.
Balance, given the waiting time we couldn't afford to stay. So I have 4 tickets in the baba...
Portugal has changed a lot, I had been there 30 years ago and I had unfortunately loved the overtourism went through and the Portuguese organization did not follow.

title: Lousy organization
text:
I don't think I've ever encountered such a lousy organization. We buy our tickets through the web with an assigned time, in our case at 11h.
When we arrived at 10.50am we met a queue of hundreds of people. We asked and were told that was the queue we had to do, whatever schedule we had. In the end it took exactly 1h47' to enter with a temperature of over 300C and without a sad shade throughout the wait. As an example, I burned my legs when I didn‚Äôt foresee that I should have worn sunscreen as if I had gone to the beach.
In the end, they only let you visit the cloister and, beautiful as it is, it is not worth all the previous suffering. If they do not improve the organization, they will lose the success they currently have.

title: Online tickets but hours in a row under the sun
text: Despite buying tickets online you have to queue for hours under the scorching sun to get in. Bad management for a UNESCO heritage site, not recommended.

title: Organisation to be reviewed
text: Hours of waiting in plain sunshine to visit 1/10th of the monastery, queue again for the church... the queue closes before the scheduled time, in short the worst experience in Lisbon

title: Deception of the century
text: It seems to me the deception of the century, two hours of queuing for 15 min visit, with how big it is and everything you could visit. Of course, it dies of a sunstroke queuing, not a sad tree, or anything for the tourist to protect from the sun, only to catch pasta and the paying tourist to give it.

title: Worst experience! Go there only if you like standing under scorching sun for hours
text: There is no point in buying online tickets. They give you a time slot but everyone, even the one without tickets, have to stand in a long queue for hours. Worst tourist experience ever!

title: Bad organization!
text: We had bought tickets online for entry from 11 to 11.30. When we got there, a kilometer line was waiting for us that ran all along the monastery! And we had to queue...hours in a row under the scorching August sun!! Absurd!!!!!! For many places now there are hourly tickets online but everyone makes sure that you can enter more or less at the scheduled time! Really bad organization!

title: Extrem bad entry conditions
text:
Catastrophic entry situation. Extrem long lines. Bad organisation. Peopel have to stay hours and hours in line under full sun.
Do not go there.

title: UNACCEPTABLE!
text: The worst organization ever! In a line, in the sun for over an hour with TIMED TICKETS!! In 2024 this is unacceptable! Is there any consumer association in Portugal that can act against this??

title: Not Worth It
text: Not sure what all the hype is about. Even though we had timed tickets, we stood in line for over an hour in the baking heat just to get into the monastery. Once in, you realize you're only seeing about 5% of what you see on the outside. That small section you do get to see is basically a stone walled courtyard with a lame fountain in the middle of it. The church next to the monastery is free but not much there either. Save yourself time and money and skip this overhyped venue.

title: Good from far & far from good
text:
After 2 hours of chaos in the sun with our e-ticket we only were allowed to see the central inner place 2 levels high. The library nor the garden were open for a visit. What a scam.
I would recommend to visit the Marina Museum: cheaper, with real e-ticket service and you see much more of the monastery & garden.

title: Pay attention to the ticket office in front of the monastery.
text:
We were scammed by the ticket office in front of the monastery. It is the official one, he made us make the tickets paid 24 ‚Ç¨ knowing that it was not possible to enter at that time for an ongoing religious service. The bishop gave instructions not to let visitors in anymore. They knew, and they sold us tickets anyway. When we asked for the money back after still standing in line for hours, only to find out that no one would come in, they told us to write an email for the refund. The refund never came. Nobody ever answered. On the receipt there is no name of the ticket office to recall them. They're gone. Not only could we not see the monastery but we did not get our money back.
Don't go to that ticket office.

We were scammed by the ticket office in front of the monastery. It is the one deemed official, he made us pay ‚Ç¨24 for tickets knowing that it was not possible to enter at that moment due to a religious function in progress. The bishop gave instructions not to allow visitors anymore. They knew this and sold us tickets anyway. When we asked for the money back after having stood in line for hours anyway, only to discover that no one would come in, they told us to write an email for a refund. The refund never arrived. Nobody ever responded. There is no name of the ticket office on the receipt to call them back. They disappeared. Not only did we not get to see the monastery but we didn't get our money back.
Don't go to that ticket office.

title: Beautiful place, bad organization
text: Bad experience, bought tickets for a time and we are lined up regardless of the time, under the sun at 40 degrees. We discover that the church is not accessible from the monastery and another queue must be queued. Too bad because the place is beautiful, bad organization. Portugal is definitely not able to handle large numbers of tourists, queues everywhere despite asking to buy tickets at a fixed time.

title: Overly crowded and long lines
text: Head Out sold us tickets as ‚Äúskip the line‚Äù; however, everyone has to stand in the same long line to get in, even if you have a ticket purchased ahead of time, and it is a ridiculously long line with more than 100 people when we went. Ultimately Head Out agreed to refund the tickets we purchased. The place itself is very nice to see from the outside. Unfortunately we did not make it inside due to the ridiculously long line in the scotching heat. It just ruins the experience.

title: Ticket sales despite closed monastery
text: The monastery and church were closed, which was pointed out very harshly at the entrance, and had sold tickets for that day online on his own homepage the same day.

title: Unpleasant treatment
text: We started with the ugly treatment given to us by a lady who sold the tickets telling us that she no longer sold the tickets by the hour, to look on the web if such, when it was still 1 1/2 hours or more before closing, all this told us in a tone of not wanting to help and not even looking into the eyes. Obviously we got the ticket on the web, no thanks to that lady who after getting the tickets that hinted that they weren't going to let us in... After coming in and being inside seeing him, an hour before the monastery closed according to his schedule we were being kicked out of there. Anyway, the worst treatment I've ever received.

title: Visit of the mosteiro dos jeronimos
text: Beautiful but!!!! Despite a ticket reserved for 10h organization of me...e with 1h queue for the visit of the cloister then still have to queue again for the church!!! Too bad it's not much to mention the bad mood of the staff

title: This place is a disrespect of visitors, tourism at its worst
text:
Don't do this with kids, teens that you try to get motivated for history and culture, or if you are not capable of standing up in a line in 30 degrees heat for an hour or more - and THEN go around and enjoy a building.
After the gruesome waiting in line outside there is nowhere to sit and rest a bit when you finally get in. There are a lot of seats but they all have signs saying you are not allowed to sit. If you sit on the ground or a doorstep the guards will be there quickly to make you get up.
The worst is that only a small fraction if the building is open for you to see. It is not worth the wait and the money.
Other reviewers say that you get in for "free" with the Lisbon Card. Oh yes, but the Lisbon Card is expensive in itself. And a pre payed ticket will not allow you to "skip the line", as several teavel bloggers state. The truth is that you only get to skip the "ticket line", but not the hour long "entrance line". And then I haven't even mentioned the third line they have: the "church line".

title: Horrible experience even buying tickets in advance. Do not go there!!! Disrespectful for elderly and children.
text: Horrible day in Jer√≥nimos. Disrespectful for children and elderly even buying tickets in advance you face a 3 hour wait

title: Skip and do something else
text:
Bought tickets for 13:00 time slot. Arrived at 12 and waited an hour (at least) in long line. There didn‚Äôt seem to be any reason for the time slot. It seemed that they only allow so many people in at a time as there were not that many people inside compared to outside waiting. But they didn‚Äôt pay attention to the ticket times upon entering.

The architecture is beautiful, but there isn‚Äôt much to see. It‚Äôs empty with the exception of a tomb. You are able to see the 2 floors that are in a square, a courtyard and a few empty rooms (1-2).

Definitely not worth the time spent waiting. Save your time and take pics of outside, unless you are very interested in architecture. I went with my 2 older teens and it was not something they cared to see. Definitely skip for younger children. It would be very boring for them.

We were also harassed the entire time we were in line by people selling stuff. There‚Äôs no where to escape so we ended up just ignoring them.

title: Run away
text: Believe the reviews. Absolutely horrific. With a ticket waited 90 minutes at opening to get in. Woman working the front is vile, cruel, and an insult to hospitality workers everywhere. Never met someone so nasty, fire immediately. Avoid this place at all costs.

title: Scam!
text: Skip this scam!! Seriously‚Äîwe showed up, went through the hassle of buying tickets using the QR website which was horrible only to find ourselves staring back at a sign saying they closed early for a strike! Save yourself the headache and visit Batalha or Alcobaca, they are way more impressive anyways!!

title: a scam
text: Real garbage and a scam. The sign at the entrance says last pass at 5:30 p.m. We arrived at 5:10 p.m. and they told us that they had already closed. Disappointing.

title: Complete disorganization
text: A profound lack of respect for customers. Even though we purchased tickets in advance, with a scheduled time, and arrived almost an hour in advance, we spent two hours in line, under the scorching Lisbon summer sun.

title: GREAT DISLIKE
text:
The misadventures associated with our visit to the monastery are associated with the inability to organize and the simple DISRESPECT of Portugal for tourists who contribute a lot of money to the treasury of this country. Complete inability/unwillingness to properly/competently organize the entry process so that people do not stand for HOURS under the scorching sun. I don‚Äôt think that, if desired, it is impossible to at least put up canopies and benches so that people can comfortably stand in a kilometer-long line to the monastery and church, which the organizers specially create for unknown reasons. We paid 12 euros for a ticket and waited for almost 2 hours under the scorching sun just to enter the monastery courtyard and walk for about 15 minutes, since there was simply nothing to do there. Entry is only allowed to the courtyard. You won't see anything else. Moreover, you won‚Äôt even be able to sit down to rest, since all the steps and stone benches have boards with the inscription DO NOT SIT. That is, centuries-old natural stones that have survived storms and earthquakes can deteriorate if 80-year-old women sit on them
who waited in line for 2 hours? And after the monastery you have to wait the same amount of time to enter the church, the entrance to which is supposedly free. The management of the establishment is hooligans and dishonest people. GREAT DISLIKE. NOT RECOMMENDED.

title: A scam for tourists
text:
What they have put together is a joke, the entrance fee is ‚Ç¨12 to see just one cloister.
On top of that, it is very poorly organized, even if you have an online ticket or, in my case, the Lisbon Card, you have to wait in the same line to enter as the people who get the ticket immediately.
If you're lucky, depending on the time, you'll wait an hour in line, if not two hours, no one will take it away from you.
It was a total disappointment what you pay for what you see.
Don't go, invest that time in another better place.

title: Worth your money, not your time
text: I will say this about the monastery, it was worth the admission price, but not at all worth your time. We had purchased the earliest time slot at 9:30, but did not get in till almost 11. For an 1 1/2 hours in line you will see a single courtyard and 3 rooms. It is very beautiful inside but there is so much hype around it that the wait makes it not worth your time. You are better off going to other places for the same amount of beauty. If you do want to go, do it through a tour group. They all got priority entry and see both the church and monastery. That was one big reason the line takes forever, they also wait for those huge groups to exit before admitting the smaller groups. I promise if you go outside a tour group you will regret it. You can see similarly beautiful places in Lisbon with a fraction of time spent.

title: Tourist trap
text: Unfortunately, I cannot tell you what I thought of the visit because I was not able to go... We had reserved our tickets in advance on the internet with an additional cost of ‚Ç¨0.60 per ticket, we are arrived on site on Tuesday June 4 at 10:30 a.m. the queue was already the length of the monastery... We asked where we should go when we already had our ticket to a security agent, who informed us that it would be necessary queue like the others, that is to say several hours in full sun at 28¬∞C, for a 15-minute visit to the monastery. For us it's no, we were only in Lisbon for two days, out of the question of waiting hours for a visit of a few minutes. It's up to you to form your own opinion but for me it's a nice tourist trap.

title: Terrible!!
text: RUDE, UNDISPONENT AND ARROGANT ticket office staff. Including the police. INFOPOINT completely useless. they only steal your salary.

title: Not a great experience.
text: Not a great experience. We bought tickets online with a half an hour time slot. We got there ten minutes before and were directed to the back of a very long queue - all of whom had pre-booked tickets. Stood for over an hour in very hot weather with no seating. We went into the monastery which was stunning but we were so hot and bothered we had a quick look before heading to the church which is part of the same complex. When we got there we could not believe we were directed outside to queue AGAIN to get into the church. I reckon it would have take us the best part of an hour to get into the church so we didn‚Äôt bother. A right shambles!

title: A shame!! There is no point in buying tickets with a specific time. A scam.
text:
A shame!! We bought the tickets online at a specific time and it was of no use, we had to wait in an endless queue with unbearable heat. It is outrageous that they sell tickets for a specific time that is not even close. After waiting for almost an hour and making no progress, we barely had to leave. There was not even staff available to solve the issue. We claimed the amount of the tickets by email without even deigning to respond.
I do not doubt the beauty of the monastery (we had already visited it a few years before) but that does not justify the poor organization and mistreatment of visitors.

title: Bad organization
text:
I had a reservation for 10am, arrived at nine we found an arrogant external guard who wouldn't let us in for the time
We waited more than two hours in the sun paying 15 euros more on the reserve ticket for nothing
DO NOT BOOK IN ADVANCE AS YOU WILL STAY IN A QUEUE
IT MAKES NO SENSE TO LEAVE HIM A 120 EURO TIP SINCE THERE WERE 8 OF US

title: Terrible planning to enter, hours in line to visit the patio alone
text: A place that is not worth entering because of the long lines that form and the little that is visible, the patio on the ground and upper floors, an empty room and another with a tomb, and that's it, stretching it out for 30 minutes. We went in May, and we spent about an hour and a half in full sun waiting to enter, very bad planning. The best thing, and it is free, is the line at the church, with much less people and much more beautiful

title: Needs Proper Facilities for those waiting hours
text: We arrived at 10.30 on Tues. The queue was hundreds long. Masses of tour groups. It was 37 degrees and there is no shade, toilets in a nearby cafe, those in the park locked. Older folks and kiddies no place to sit. Given the money this rakes in something better needs to be provided. I am sure it is lovely but we left as no way is it worth the wait for us in that heat and its only May....btw a certain search engine has stopped accepting negative reviews for it, says it all really.

title: No tickets via the internet
text:
Bought tickets with a time slot via the internet. We were able to stand at the back of the Lisboa tickets. We have about 150 people in front of us. People are being admitted gradually. Advice not to buy tickets online with a time slot.
Was on May 22nd.

title: Misleading...scams...there is no way to get in without being in a huge queue...even with a ticket purchased online.
text: A little shame. Even if we buy tickets online we still have to go to the entrance queue and the queue to enter is huge in the sun or in the rain. It's a lie when tour operators and supposed guides sell the tour as skip the line...Skip the line. This does not exist in Portugal. They should be prosecuted for deceiving people.

title: SKIP the cloisters visit - it is seriously overrated
text: The single most overrated attraction in Lisbon. It costs 12‚Ç¨ per person to go inside and 1-3 hour queues. Not even close to worth it for what‚Äôs actually inside. My advice: see the outside - it‚Äôs free and most important no queue. If you want, visit the church (queue on right). It‚Äôs also free and a much shorter queue. Save your ‚Ç¨‚Ç¨ and time and SKIP the cloisters (queue on left).

title: You‚Äôre not missing much by not coming here !
text: Queued for 30 mins plus. You really see only a small part of the monastery - Chapel/burial chamber, refectory and cloister. You come out & have to queue again to into the church. Limited information about the place, but the stone carving is incredible. Takes only 20-30 minutes. Waste of money and time.

title: Jeronimos Monastery: Vastly Overrated
text: The exterior is really quite beautiful. The interior, while also interesting (and even beautiful), but wasn‚Äôt worth the price of admission, much less the two hours and five minutes I had to stand in line just to get in‚Äîand that was after buying tickets online in advance. Very disappointing.

title: HEADOUT is a scam - don‚Äôt use them.
text:
DO NOT BOOK A TOUR HERE WITH HEADOUT
We booked ‚Äúskip the line tickets‚Äù with a guide for the monestary and tower. We spent e‚Ç¨20 to get here, waited around for almost an hour. When no one showed, we called and were told the tour was canceled. No notification, nothing. It‚Äôs a scam. They take your money, and the refund doesn‚Äôt come for a week. Don‚Äôt do it.

title: Two perspectives
text: You have to look at it from two perspectives. The building is gigantic and more than worth seeing, but we were there half an hour before it opened and waited patiently for 1.5 hours in the blazing sun. After that we couldn't go into the church because we would have had to queue again in the other line because of the heat. The toilets are a disgrace. You can't go there urgently, they are cramped, dirty and... groups are given priority, so each individual pays more. Oh, and then there is a Lisboa card where you are still asked to pay. It seems to me that they can't get enough. It's a shame that there aren't other solutions.

title: Long lines, could not even see the whole attraction!
text:
Long story short, the line was so long that we couldn't see most of this attraction. Rude staff. Here's what happened:

The Jeronimos Monastery in Lisbon opens at 9:30 AM. We arrived right before 9:30 AM and there was already a long line. That's ok - we got in line. A worker there asked us if we were with a tour group and we said no. He said we had to get out of this line and go into a different line. We were confused but we said ok and got into the other line. By now, it was later, so that line was even longer. We waited in line for over 1 hour despite getting there right when it opened. We also got tickets beforehand but it didn't matter.

They let us into the cloister but not the church. When we left the cloister we discovered there is no way to get into the church which is the main part of this attraction! We talked to a security guard and asked how to get inside. He said we had to go BACK into the line we were originally in - the line that the other man told us to get out of. It was so disorganized. At this point, the line was so long, that we would have been waiting 2 or 3 hours just to see the rest of it, if we got into that line.

I don't understand why they have 2 lines in the first place - shouldn't you just wait in line and see everything once inside? We ended up just leaving because we didn't want to stand in direct sunlight for 2-3 hours. So we paid all this money and we were not even able to see the majority of this attraction.

title: Lack of respect for visitors
text: We were so looking forward to visiting Mosteiro dos Jeronimos but after waiting an hour in full sun, finally getting in to discover we would later have to exit then join another queue to visit the church we were so disappointed. You queue on the left for the cloisters and the right for the church. When you get into the Cloister area which you pay extra for, every seat has signs saying do not sit down, the cloisters are surrounded by stone seating, this seems so ridiculous, after the long wait, a short sit down would have been nice! We abandoned the other queue and called it a day. There is no signposting and many people had queued for ages only to discover you have to buy tickets across the road.

title: Terrible entry management
text: Even though we had bought the tickets online days before, once we arrived we discovered that we had to stand in not one but two endless queues, which would have made us waste hours (under a scorching sun). Unfortunately we decided to leave due to the terrible organization!

title: Very expensive for what it is...NOT RECOMMENDED!
text:
Reading people's comments we have read that the organization was regrettable but that it was worth going to see it. We decided to buy the ticket for ‚Ç¨12 and after waiting an hour and a quarter (at lunchtime, since we went first thing in the morning and there were many more people) the duration of the visit is approximately 20 minutes. 20 minutes in which you see a simple two-story patio (nice to take two photos) and a couple of empty rooms.
NOT WORTH IT!!!

title: Long queues
text: Didn‚Äôt go in, too busy. There is no point going if you are just ticking the box unless you really interested in it art. Crazy queues

title: Jeronimo Monastery
text: Seen from the outside, magnificent, an organization to be reviewed, don't take the wrong queue because otherwise, it's back to the queue. Paid 20 euros to see not much, don't waste your time, the photo of the exterior is free and is more than enough.

title: Don't bother
text: The place is beautiful but not even close to worth having to wait 3 hours to get into and you couldn't really tell why the line moved so slow but you will literally waste a half of a day of your precious time here waiting to get in, don't bother.

title: Never got in
text: We bought tickets in advance for a timed entry but when we showed up 30 min before our time the line was so long it was simply not possible to comprehend. The line was perhaps 1500 people long. The guide we talked to said she had never seen a line this long, ever. And this was just a Thursday morning. We waited 90 min, the line moved maybe 50 feet and by that estimate we would wait another 4 hours. We gave up and left. No refunds!

title: Nice but terrible organization - 3 hours in line
text: Beautiful cloister but terrible organization. Slot tickets not considered. 3 hours in line to enter (only in the cloister). You can see it inside in 10 minutes and it could accommodate double the number of people, reducing the queue. To enter the church (for which you paid the ticket) you have to go out and queue again. Organization completely to be reviewed.

title: Not worth it.
text:
The monastery is magnificent, no doubt about it.

BUT everything else needs to be reviewed.

Time-stamped tickets are futile because you have to queue with others. The Lisboa Card allows you to avoid queuing at the ticket office but you also have to queue with others.

And what a tail! Expect a 2-hour queue if you don't come 30 minutes before opening.

And that‚Äôs not the worst (nothing is wrong)! Groups come before everyone else. There is only one person to validate tickets. And once inside, no information. We are left to our own devices. So we spend 30 minutes there not understanding anything of what we see.

Honestly, if we had known all this before, we wouldn't have done it.

And the church? It is certainly free but the queue is not short and even when leaving the monastery you have to queue again. In short, we went on our way to the church.

Don't waste your time and money here.

title: Nice but poorly organised
text: A small disappointment, the monastery is beautiful, impeccably maintained but to access the church you have to queue for another very long time, 1 and a half hours of queuing to see the monastery and then another queue of at least 1 hour

title: Timed entry? Who cares??
text: What a zoo! I don‚Äôt like me to write negative reviews but this experience was not good. In spite of paying for timed entry, there was no consideration for trying to plan ahead. The line went forever- maybe 500 people in line on a Tuesday morning. Didn‚Äôt even get in to see the interior. I guess the way to go is by a guided tour. What a disappointment.

title: DON'T GO. DON'T WASTE 3 HOURS OF YOUR TIME. IT'S NOT WORTH IT
text:
DO NOT GO. I REPEAT DO NOT GO
The organization must be one of the most regrettable in Europe. The time of online entry is worthless. Everyone is in the same line.
There are 2 lines, one for tours and the other for individuals. But YOU HAVE TO GUESS WHICH IS WHICH. NO ONE INFORMS ANYTHING. Apart from that, the guards are very annoying. Zero kindness to tourists.
After the epic you manage to enter and at the end it is a large patio that in countries like Italy, Scotland, England, Spain, Germany, Hungary, etc. would pass as just another one.
It's a scam. One of the worst things I've seen in europq. DON'T GO. I'LL THANK YOU

title: Go on your way!!
text: Arriving at 9:30 a.m. we asked a guide where to queue: he showed us a queue (the one on the right) where we began to wait. We approach the door around 10:30 a.m., a 1 hour wait for the person at the entrance to tell us that the line we are in is that of groups (several people behind us in the same situation) and asks us to go queue again in the second line (on the left) where there are already a hundred people!!!! The staff doesn't want to hear anything and doesn't let us pass (us + the few people behind us who, like us, waited 1 hour). Our tickets having already been purchased, we still decided to wait in line in the left lane. We returned around 12:15 p.m., a total wait of 2:30 to 2:45 hours with tickets purchased in advance on the internet... The visit is very quick (30 min) and is not at all worth the 2:30 hours of waiting. The height of the visit: you have to queue again to enter the Church (the one on the right which strangely is no longer that of the groups?!). Unfriendly staff and giving incorrect information. A word of advice: move on, there are much more beautiful places in Lisbon.

title: If you like queues!!!!!
text: Reservation made on the official website, online ticket for 10 a.m., arrival on site at 9:15 a.m., already more than 100 meters in line, while the monument opens at 9:30 a.m. and the site indicates that they sell 300 tickets every half hour? ?? We returned at 11:00 a.m. after the groups, and don't think about visiting the church because you will have to queue again, the organization needs to be completely reviewed, a shame because the cloister is magnificent

title: Lousy organization!!
text:
Catastrophic organization: all groups have priority and pass in front of the poor tourists who wait for hours in the sun without the possibility of sitting down. Lots of coaches and cruise ships arrive after you and you in front!!
Arrived 50 minutes before opening and spent 1/2 hour after opening behind 500 cruise tourists üò§üò°
Simply SHAMEFUL!!

title: Splendid example of supertourism
text: We bought tickets online and arrived at the opening. Nonetheless we were in queue for an hour. When we entered the queue had quadrupled in size. Inside there is a beautiful cloister and a beautiful refectory, for a total of 2 rooms. Once out we had to visit the church, the third room included in the ticket, but in the meantime the hour-long queue had moved to the entrance of the church, so we left. The next day we went to the less known Sao Vicente de Fora monastery: ten times bigger, ten times more beautiful, zero queues. Here is the difference between tourism and overtourism.

title: CAUTION - Be aware before planning to visit
text: This place is shockingly very unorganised so be prepared to buy a ticket but not actually go inside, whether you pre-book or not. Don't be fooled by "Timeslots" either they are meaningless you will join the humongous queue and wait for a MINIMUM 1 HOUR with everybody else whether they have a timeslot or not. On the side of the Monastry there are signs saying ticket office but then another sign which makes you realise there is a booth across the road which is the ticket office, this also has a queue. Do NOT be fooled by them telling everyone it will be a 20 minute wait, once you see the queue over the road you will realise that is impossible. I think the only way you may have a short wait would be to have pre-booked slot and be the first in the queue when they open or go before they close but then you may not have enough time in there. The guy at the ticket booth who served us (dark hair and beard) was very rude to everyone, not a good first impression for a monastry visit. After buying the tickets and making our way to the end of the L-O-N-G queue we quickly realised it was hopeless and we had wasted our money. We wanted to ask (longshot I know) for a refund but the queue was long at the ticket office and there were others up there coming back for refunds so we didn't want to waste more of our precious time and didn't bother. It would have been unlikely anyway as the guy was not customer friendly. All was not lost as we gave our tickets away so hopefully some good came out of this, if they eventually got in. We asked if we could use these the next day but this was refused. If you decide to go here I would suggest if more than one of you, one join the queue at the monastry and the other go for the tickets. It was interesting to see a Police presence around the ticket office, makes you wonder if a lot of unhappy people go back there having been misled at how long the wait is?

title: Not worth the money and time
text:
After standing in line for 1.5 hours, you are back outside in 15 minutes.
You only visit the courtyard behind the church. You don't see anything of the monastery.
So it really wasn't worth it

title: Don't bother. You will queue for 3 hours even if you pre-purchase a ticket. Not worth it. They need to organise bookings into ti
text: You will be queuing for 3 hours no matter if you pre-purchase a ticket or not. Very unclear signage for the lines. No time slots booking to limit queuing. Terrible organisation.

title: Complete waste of money! Do not pay for cloisters!
text: The Monastery was a total disappointment and a complete rip off of ‚Ç¨12 to visit the cloisters. You purchase a time entry but the time literally means nothing. I had a timed slot for 11:30, but when I got to the line at 11:15, the guards said it didn‚Äôt matter what time my ticket said. They just point you to the end of a long line. The line took 1 hour to enter the cloisters. The cloisters take just 15 minutes to get through and there are very few descriptive signs to tell you more about what you‚Äôre seeing. They really need to add an audio guide, more signs, or a museum component. Absolute waste of your time and money! Instead, just go the church for free.

title: BE WARNED OF INSANE LINE UPS OF 2 - 3 HOURS! TIQETS ARE SCAM ARTISTS
text:
We purchased tickets through Tiqets (MISTAKE). There was no disclaimer about how many tickets they sell per day or to how long the queues could be. Normally when one purchases tickets for a venue they are given priority access or a time to queue.

We arrived in the rain and the line up was absolutely unbelievable - so much so we asked the security guard how long would the wait be and he stated 2-3 hours and when we asked if there was a time of day that would be better he stated that it‚Äôs always like this.

Needless to say that I could not physically stand for 2-3 hours, in the rain.
I explained my story to Tiqets and they basically told me that they would never offer a refund.

So beware of this venue. I‚Äôd probably suggest to arrive prior to opening.

title: A shameful wonder
text: The cloister is truly spectacular but the organization is terrible! The Lisboa card turned out to be decidedly useless as it does not give access priority and we had to queue for 1 hour to enter (I therefore advise against purchasing it). To visit the church you have to queue again for the same duration. I don't understand the limited entry as the cloister is very large and could have accommodated more people. The staff is very rude and the signs for access are non-existent. If we think that it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, we are astonished.

title: Entry system is awful
text: Currently waiting in the rain in the queue to enter the monastery. We have waited over an hour and looks like at least half an hour more. We bought tickets on line. No system to control the number of people who arrive. A simple booking and timed slot system would solve this issue. I hope it‚Äôs worth the wait when we get in, there is a similar queue for the church.

title: Make sure you check the length of the queue before buying tickets
