text: Buying tickets is a weird set up. Normally you would buy tickets for a museum, church etc. at the entrance to the building. Here you have to buy tickets across the road in a booth type place. From here it is impossible to see the length of the queue to get into the monastery. Today, having queued up to buy our tickets (incidentally from a very rude employee), we were told the queue was 20 minutes long to get in. However, when we crossed the road, the queue literally went on forever and having watched the small number of people who were allowed in at any one time, we calculated that the wait time would be at least 1-2 hours. This is a total rip off. A simple board stating an accurate waiting time would help people decided whether they were prepared to queue for this amount of time. We chose not to, as it was far too long for an elderly person to stand in a queue. We gave our tickets away. Such a shame as we were all looking forward to see it. My advice is check the wait time before buying your tickets.

title: Beautiful but terrible organization
text:
The monastery is wonderful but unfortunately I have to leave a terrible review because after the visit to the monastery...we wanted to get back in line to see the church as there are 2 divided entrances but it was closed for a religious function i.e. a wedding.... the sign it didn't say the reopening time... lots of people waiting without any information... they then tell us that it reopens at 2pm but it's already 2.20pm and no one can be seen.
How is it possible to allow a wedding on an opening day with such a turnout when Monday is closed!!!
It is neither commentable nor tolerable!

title: A rip-off
text: Not even one star for me. A ticket for 12‚Ç¨ and a long queue, what's the point??? The building is beautiful from the outside but all the rooms are closed. I think they want us to pay the renovation costs.

title: Very underwhelming!
text: Underwhelming! Long queue basically just see a courtyard for 10 mins. Nothing really to see inside, no information and you're restricted to a very small area of the overall Monastery. Most interesting part of the visit was watching the grumpy security guards answering the same dumb questions from tourists who don't understand how to buy a ticket or join a queue!

title: Fantastic architectural wonder, but worth the wait and price?
text: Jeronimos Monastery in itself is a beautiful and detailed monastery. However, there were a lot that I didn't like as much. First of all queue. I was a bit shocked by the line that was already there. So once waiting, it basically went quickly. Still waited 45 minutes. So expectations are high. Once inside you don't see much other than the monastery itself. All doors, windows and rooms are locked. So you don't see much. I at least expected some information boards and some old photos. This meant I was looking forward to half an hour. There were 2 rooms open. A tomb and another room. Finally, traveling by public transport from the center of Lisbon to Jeronimos is easy. Many possibilities. If you like Architecture Jeronimos is fantastic, but going inside is not worth the wait and price. Then looking from the outside is sufficient.

title: A rain program, not in the rain
text:
The weather forecast was unmistakable. A rainy day. A day, no doubt, for the museums. A day for the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. It wasn't easy to even get there because many visitors thought the same. It was cold, but the wonder of this world heritage site kept us entertained. A tourist must. A building of unique beauty and uniqueness. A masterpiece of Manueline architecture. But the constant rain had consequences. Shortly before the end of our visit, we were simply thrown out. And that wasn't enough, we weren't allowed into the Basilica of S.Maria de Belem at all. The emergency service was laughable. We didn't get our tickets refunded or offered an alternative date. Get out!! Don't get in!! The devil take you, admirers of beauty and uniqueness.
Gherardino

title: Very underwhelmed
text: When you see the queues you think that this is really worth seeing as the architecture on the outside looks great. After paying ‚Ç¨12 each to wander round a few rooms and the cloister we were underwhelmed and felt that the entry fee was over the top. The church was good, but not worth the money.

title: Rather underwhelming compared to other attractions in the area
text: Definitely over rated! Went to see this place after reading reviews and wish I hadn‚Äôt bothered. Queued for ages for tickets whilst at the same time managed to buy on line, however these tickets then took an age to come through via email. Eventually got in and although the place is impressive, felt there wasn‚Äôt really much to see compared to other places we have visited in and around Lisbon. If you dont have much time in Lisbon, there are better things to see, for example the Castle, the Carmo Convent or even a trip to Sintra

title: Beautiful but Disappointing
text: Visited 18 Jan 2024. 12 euros each to enter but unfortunately the only part one gets to see is the internal cloisters. No access to the confessionals or living quarters etc. Very little info explaining life over the years in the monastery and the staff were keen to walk away when approached. A truly beautiful building that is worth visiting but it doesn‚Äôt take long to walk around (15 mins even when reading the few info plaques) and tbh 12 euro‚Äôs is a con, especially given the ridiculous queues just to get tickets during the busier times. The church next door is free where the architecture is stunning. All in all only 2 stars for a beautiful but quite disappointing experience. Tip. Go to the church instead but if you must enter the monastery do so in low season and check in advance because they are prone to random closures for inexplicable reasons.

title: Avoid
text: Purchased a ticket online via the official website. Arrived on the day to be find that it was closed and we weren't allowed in. I've emailed and called trying to get a refund and haven't had a response. Not a great look for tourism in Lisbon, but found that to be the case throughout the city...

title: scam
text: We had purchased tickets to visit the site on December 31; what was our disappointment to find the site closed even though the website literally indicated "open" until 6 p.m.!

title: Wonderful but impossible!
text: I was shocked by the infinite queue to enter the cloister of this wonderful building. It seems there is nothing else to visit in the nearbys. I took pics from the outside, but I prefer not ti visit overcrowded sites. Maybe if you book online in advance you can save some time, but the experience is tiring.

title: Despite having a ticket, I had to queue for an outrageous length of time twice, poor organisation
text:
On the one hand, very beautiful architecture, on the other hand, you have to queue forever only to then have to queue AGAIN to get into the church right next door. We didn't have enough time, the queues were just too long. (Despite buying our tickets early!) The security people were also extremely unfriendly. I almost had the impression that they like to use their opportunity to stop tourists and reprimand them. As a cautious and friendly person, I didn't feel comfortable.
In addition, you can only visit one courtyard and two rooms, which is very disappointing. The building seems to be much bigger. There was also no information about the history of the monastery and life there (no signs, no audio guide, nothing). I would have liked more insight into the past. As it is, it is nothing more than a pretty photo spot, which you could get for free in many church courtyards and cloisters.

title: Bad experience
text: Very nice and historically relevant building, however poor organization, expensive for what it is and bad experience. We ran in at 5:25 p.m. because despite closing at 6:30 p.m. they cut off the passage (and the entrances at 5:00 p.m.), when we entered they were already telling us to be ‚Äúlight‚Äù. We went straight to the bathroom at the entrance, surprised that only women's toilets were available, neither men nor disabled (closed), nor was one of the women's bathrooms enabled for them (and keeping an eye on them just in case). After this, we went to start the visit, but not before explaining that we had just entered, because they wanted to kick us out without seeing us. We entered and the guide continually followed us, telling us that they were closing (it was 5:35 p.m.) and to the few remaining visitors. We saw them in 10 minutes, literally. When leaving, other visitors who were not allowed to pass were arguing with the guides because of the bad indications of prohibiting access... they should indicate that they close at 5:30 p.m.... anyway, bad experience, if you go, go early.

title: Accessibility 0
text:
The cloister is a work of art, but accessibility is terrible and non-existent. As you do not exceed 60% disability you have to pay the full entrance fee, you pay it and ask where the elevator is, the answer was "there is none, you can only visit the ground floor" surprising
Portugal has a lot to advance in terms of accessibility, it has major deficiencies.

title: Service for ticket sales is horrible, the totems were not working and the customer service employee was arrogant
text: Service for ticket sales is terrible, the totems were not working and the customer service employee was arrogant and xenophobic.

title: A scam to avoid
text: A scam to avoid at all costs from the outside the building is magnificent and when we arrived in Lisbon it was really the first monument that we wanted to see so I went to the ticket office at 4:58 p.m. to buy 3 tickets using a credit card from the machine tells me payment accepted but the tickets do not come out the 2 ladies on site tell me that they have to pay again even though I had already paid but what should I do so I paid twice for the entrance. The next day I noticed the obvious theft on my bank. I went to the ticket office and found the same people who told me they could do nothing and to contact asset management by email. I send an email and they ask me to send the tickets that I didn't get and the others that I threw away at the end of the visit... In short, be wary and know that we risk you charging twice for a visit which in addition after an episode like this or in a foreign country we are defrauded we really have the impression of being pigeons

title: The line is long!!!!
text:
As other reviewers have warned, a visit to the monastery may not be a wise expenditure of precious travel time. I would not advise buying tickets on line but suggest going to Belem and purchasing tickets from an uncrowded office across the street - IF you can see that the monastery line is not long. We arrived with tickets in hand about 10:30 on Halloween and saw a line stretching the length of the building and around the corner. The line for the interesting church was short and we enjoyed our visit there, but we scuttled plans to tour the cloisters when it‚Äôs line had not shortened. Rain was predicted, so we ate the cost of the tickets. Why does the monastery not offer time slots?

The Explorers Monument is remarkable and Belem offers other reasons to visit. However, be flexible about the logistics of getting there from Lisbon. Following Rick Steve‚Äôs lead, we tried to take the 15E bus but watched two westbound buses pass by the Corpo Santo stop because each was already packed with passengers. Two similarly frustrated but kind tourists offered to share a cab with us.

I expect the monastery is as beautiful as others state and wish the monastery would offer time slots.

title: Disgusting Security Staff
text:
Me and my pregnant wife arrived at the monostary at 9:30am, as we have always wanted to visit it and see it in person. It was cold and raining but we didn't mind waiting as we really wanted to see inside the monastery. My wife was getting quite cold from the rain and the line was very long, so after 30 minutes of standing & waiting in the rain, I quickly went to a coffee shop and brought some coffee back for my pregnant wife - the aim being that we could drink it quickly before we got inside.

The security guard - whose name was Diogo Oliveira - aggressively and abruptly came walking towards me and my pregnant wife in front of everyone. He pulled the barrier back and told me to throw my coffee away and go back to the end of the queue. I politely questioned him why, and he kept speaking loudly telling me to throw my coffee away and to go through the barrier and line up at the back again - after 1hr of waiting.

Me and my wife were very confused and we calmly and politely tried to reason with him to descalate the issue - something he should be trained at doing. He continued speaking very aggressively and made an entire scene in the line with people watching and feeling uncomfortable.

Me and my wife were extremely embarrassed at this point and were shocked that a member of staff - whose sole purpose is to provide security - would escalate such a small issue that could have been dealt with politely and discreetly in order to not to make people feel belittled and embarrassed.

The issue was only resolved as me and my wife refused to go to the back and simply offered to throw our coffee away in the bin - which he eventually agreed to once a police officer came over to see what was going on.

I am disgusted that a member of staff would behave in this way towards tourist. It is unacceptable and completely wrong.

title: Worst Part of Lisbon - Avoid - Not Worth It!
text:
Absolutely awful experience . Have never been treated as rudely by multiple employees as I was at Jer√≥nimos Monastery. The rest of Lisbon is so pretty and so unique, don‚Äôt spend a second dealing with the morons that run this place, or waiting in hours-long lines.

To try and sum up the worst part of Lisbon‚Ä¶ The cloister (commonly called ‚Äúthe monastery‚Äù) is a complete waste of time. It‚Äôs a small courtyard with some nicely done carved pillars/walls. You need to pay 12 Euro to get in. You need to wait in line 90+ minutes to get in. Don‚Äôt listen to anywhere that says ‚Äúskip the line‚Äù - you can‚Äôt. You circle the courtyard twice and are out in 10 min.

There is also a ‚Äúchurch‚Äù. This part is free. It has a separate line that is usually slightly shorter. In the mornings, this line is insane, as tour groups cut in and out, and you will be yelled at to buy a ticket and get in the paid line for the cloister even if you want to just see the free church. It is clear employees have been told to bully you into paying to see the cloister.

The worst part is, even if you get in to see the cloister after waiting in line, you then have to come out and get back in line AGAIN to see the church. The church is nice - but wouldn‚Äôt put it in the top 15 most impressive churches that I‚Äôve seen in Europe.

My advice - steer clear of this whole place. The garden in front is beautiful, and the exterior of the entire building is by far the most impressive part. Just enjoy a leisurely walk around the building and then go see the rest of beautiful Belem. The walking tour of Belem that we took with Sara was A+.

If anyone from the government or Catholic Church reads this - please do anything in your power to talk to the staff on site. I have simply never been treated this way in my life - not just by one problem employee having a bad day - but by three separate employees. Absurd.

title: Pitiful organization unworthy of a monument of such heritage value
text: Despite difficulties obtaining our entry tickets, we queued in front of the monastery for the second time before learning that the site was closed due to a strike.

title: Great Expectations
text:
Great expectations were dashed upon our visit to this much touted monastery. A friend and I queued for approximately an hour and a half (don‚Äôt be misled: buying tickets on line affords you no advantage) in wet and windy conditions, anticipating a rich, historical experience. Sadly, the opposite was true. The visit consisted of circling the upper level and looking down on the quad, a quick visit to a tiled room which had been the refectory, then circling the lower level and looking onto the quad from a different vantage point. The entire visit, as outlined above, but with a quick visit to the Ladies, took fifteen minutes.
A colossal disappointment.

title: Prefer other monasteries in Portugal!
text:
The first time monastery closed due to official visit no information
And today in place in the queue for the opening and at the time of opening monastery on strike closes today no sign before a shame they even let you buy the tickets 10 minutes before

title: Queuing Nightmare
text:
Worth seeing but spoiled by ticketing and queuing arrangements. It needs online, timed entry that allows single not separate access to monastery and church.
Selling untimed tickets online that have to be redeemed at a central tourist information office is a ridiculous way to access a major attraction.
The on site ticket office was shut on alternate Sundays including the day we opted to visit.
As Oscar Wilde remarked in a different context, 'worth seeing, not worth going to see.'

title: Not really worth visiting
text: The monastery isn't really worth visiting, especially considering the price of the tickets. The logic of the tour is come-see-go. In order to achieve that, there signs at every bench in the monastery informing us that seating is forbidden. I wouldn't recommend visiting the monastery but I would 100% recommend visiting the Santa Maria Church at the entrance of the monastery which is really beautiful and it also free to enter.

title: Bad organization that ruins the experience
text: We had booked our tickets in advance thinking of avoiding the line. On site, more than 2 hours of waiting. We had to cancel the visit and lost our tickets. Poor organization, to be avoided. Even if you have already purchased the tickets, you have to queue for the church and then queue again for the cloister.

title: Waste of a day
text: Ridiculous hours long wait. Stupidly long line even with advance tickets purchased online. What a total crock! Stand in this line for 90 mins (at least) oh and you wanna see the church? Go stand in that line for another 90 mins. They are next to each other! I will never go again. There are dozens of monasteries and churches in Portugal that don‚Äôt have freakishly long lines. AVOID.

title: Despite trying three times I couldn't get in and then gave up.
text: Getting tickets is a challenge! The ticket booth closes early or it closes because of storms and rain! The Headout app is unable to send a ticket within 30 minutes. We had to queue soaking wet in the rain; a roof for the waiting crowds of visitors would have been quite appropriate. We were eventually sent back out into the rain twice by security guards... Then we gave up and cancelled the online tickets.

title: Terrible service , underwhelming attraction which does not deserve the massive queue.
text:
This was the biggest let down of our trip. Once inside the visit takes 10 minutes at most and is completely underwhelming comprising some cloisters, an austere chapel and a tiled refectory and THAT IS IT.
Booking online we did not expect much of a wait but on arriving there was at least a 100 metre queue which took a hour and a half, with no shelter and being constantly pestered by hawkers and beggars. This also was in the middle of a complete rainstorm which left the whole queue literally soaked to the skin. Why did we not give up? Well some people did‚Ä¶but having paid already and given the lack of information about how uninteresting this attraction actually is, most people opted to wait. If you don‚Äôt book online you have to buy tickets from a mirrored booth across the road which is partly obscured by trees. We came to the conclusion that this was a cynical ploy to keep people in the interminable queue.
The problem was that the staff controlling access to the monastery only let one or two people in at a time, sometimes with about a 15 minute wait in between admissions. This did not appear to be for any apparent reason other than being a jobsworth or on a whim and maybe enjoying the sight of increasingly bedraggled tourists. The staff were not monitoring how crowded the venue was nor were they in any radio contact with anyone inside. We would imagine that in summer weather the problem would also be the total lack of shade. When we got inside the numbers of people were very scarce and could certainly have taken some more visitors to relieve the sodden masses outside. Finally there was a massive queue for the ladies toilets which were filthy.

title: The vote is for disorganization!
text: The vote is for total disorganization and not for the Monastery which is truly wonderful and unmissable. I find it sincerely embarrassing that despite having purchased the ticket online with a specific time, you have to queue much earlier and still enter well after the time (we had booked for 10.00, we queued at 9.40 and entered shortly before 11am). Furthermore, this is not made explicit anywhere and the staff must continually repeat it to all tourists who ask for information. Furthermore, once inside there are no audio guides... or even illustrative brochures. Considering the level of the monument it's a shame!

title: Rude and disorganized
text: Absolutely disorganized and shockingly rude. This scathing review primarily centers on the abysmal organization and mistreatment of independent tourists attempting to visit the church. The staff exhibits zero willingness to offer assistance or answer even the most fundamental inquiries about queuing procedures or the church's opening time, despite the official sources clearly stating 10:30 AM. On the day of our visit, they arbitrarily decided to delay the opening until 11 AM, while granting preferential entry to groups from Viking Cruises and similar organizations. The rest of us were seemingly dismissed with indifference. If you're contemplating an early start to secure your spot in line, well, you're in for a challenge. Good luck with that.

title: Disrespect
text: Horrible experience, disrespect for people, kilometer queue, even if purchasing in advance online, could restrict the number of people per day, increase the price, etc. Disorganized is not worth it. 4 hours in line! In the sun

title: Most Unorganized Site in the World
text: After visiting sites on 6 continents I would have to say this is one of the most unorganized I have ever seen. The monastery opens around 930 or so. I had a Lisboa Card which was supposed to give me quick access to the site. Some other people also had timed tickets that would give them quick access. Unfortunately they put everyone in the same line: quick access, timed tickets and those that just bought tickets. I got there at around 920 and stood in line for over an hour and they let in only 20 people per hour. I counted the people in front of me and figured it would take another 2 hours to get in. Behind me the line stretched for a mile or so. There was no point to prebooking or getting a Lisboa card for this. I walked away and figured I would not waste any more of my life in the line. This site is an embarrassment to Portugal. Avoid at all costs.

title: Viewing is not worth the amount!
text:
Ask if everything can be viewed! We stood in line for an hour and bought tickets online while in line. In the meantime, we saw that people who entered the wrong way were simply put at the front by the unfriendly staff. Finally inside, beautiful courtyard, what you would expect. You will have seen this after 20-30 minutes. Then you want to go further into the church, and you are simply sent outside with the message: the church is now closed for 3 hours for the ceremony.
And you pay eur 12 for that...a waste of money, look at the outside and see the inside in photos on the internet.

title: Great monastry, poor organization
text: They sell tickets for time slots, however, are unable to organize the access to the monastry. We had to queue over 90 minutes‚Ä¶ however, the monastry is superb

title: Bad experience due to queue management
text: Lots of people and no queue management. We purchased our tickets in advance with a specific time, and when we arrived there was at least a 2 hour line. We gave up and lost our 2 entries

title: What a desappointment
text:
No skip-the-line tickets for reservations on the site we queue.
After a good hour, visit folded into 15 minutes.
And repeat to visit the church.
Let's summarize:
Not an essential visit, the exterior is more than enough.
If you can, prefer Alcobaca, Maffra, Batalha, much prettier and full of history.
Too bad ü§¶üòî

title: If you like endless queues when you have a Timed slot ticket, this is for you.
text: The review is not about the place. You have already gotten it‚Äôs worth visiting from the number and score of the reviews. Problem is it does not matter if you have a ticket with the time on it to skip the queue, which you have bought choosing a time slot due to availability. You still have to wait one hour in the queue with all the other disappointed ticket owners complaining with you. At least you‚Äôll be in good company. It is embarrassing a more organised system is not in place. Oh, if you do not have a ticket, expect a long queue to get the ticket first and then the other long queue to get in with your brand new ticket. It‚Äôs ridiculous. It is 2023, wake up.

title: Explain the time slot on the ticket!
text:
The place is beautiful, but independently from the time on your ticket (if you book online) you have to queue for long time, like hours. If you book online you can choose a time slot, the funny thing is you also have availabilities, but is a total scam because it doesn‚Äôt matter at all.
We were lucky enough not to queue under the sun, but I assume that in summer it might become a nightmare.

title: All that for this‚Ä¶
text:
Having purchased tickets for the 2 p.m. slot‚Ä¶. We arrived a little early and saw the queue for ticket holders‚Ä¶. We waited 45 minutes to enter the monastery... the visit lasted 20 minutes... I have seen better monasteries with better content... there it was empty and the management needs to be reviewed!!

Then you can visit the church next door but no‚Ä¶ you have to go out and queue again‚Ä¶

Don't waste your time!

title: Not worth the detour
text: Bad experience, 2 hours of waiting for a 20mm tour of the monastery. Then you have to queue again for another 1.5 hours to visit the church, certainly very pretty but the wait is not worth the detour. The view of the monument from the outside is more than enough in my opinion and is not worth the 3.5 hour wait. I don't recommend it at all, I'm not even talking about the entrance price of 12 euros. Tourist trap for me

title: A Dantesque circle
text: I won't add anything more than what others have already said. Both the Monastery and the Igreja deserve three stars but no more, I have seen truly amazing sites in Spain. What infuriates me is the total disorganization I have seen everywhere in Portugal. It is not logical to have to queue for about an hour under the August sun to access the church and then queue for another hour and a half to access the adjacent monastery. There were people not used to the heat in serious difficulty. No preferential access for those who purchased the ticket online or the Lisboa card. Absurd. I absolutely don't recommend it.

title: A bad experience
text:
Having to queue for over 1 hour in the sun with no shade and no seating with no opportunity to purchase or obtain water is not a good start. For over people it could be life threatening.
With tickets being purchased on line why is there not a timed admission system?
When insudevthercis nowhere where one is allowed to sit ( well there is one but you can't see anything) to rest one's tired legs
Infactvsawcobe elderly man told off for leaning on a wall.
If its hot and a queue avoid its just not worth the wait.

title: Waiting time is unreasonable
text: We've been waiting in line for an hour (despite having a ticket) and it will probably take another 1-2 hours. Poorly organized entry. Organizing a visit to such a great building so poorly is really a feat. What a pity.

title: 2 stars only for the beauty of the place
text:
As soon as we arrived, we were thrown out by security: they were no longer letting people in before the designated time.

Once we showed that we had the tickets, he first didn't believe us and then had to let us in, all in a rude and aggressive tone.

Inside the monastery, which is magnificent by the way, the staff followed us to each room to let us leave.

The staff has spoiled the beauty of the monument‚Ä¶

title: Line too long
text:
Be prepared to wait in line for hours, under the scorching sun. There is no need to buy the ticket in advance or the Lisboa card, there is only one queue for everyone. Poor organization. I am speechless.

Buying tickets online or Lisboa card won't let you skip the queue. So be prepared to be in queue for hours.

title: Not worth it
text: Even overlooking the endless queue under the sun, and the uselessness of the time indicated on the ticket purchased online, the building is beautiful but if you have already seen the monasteries of Batalha or Alcoba√ßa it adds nothing, especially if you consider that it is practically accessible the cloister alone. It is definitely worth just seeing the church: beautiful, free and with very little queue.

title: This place suscks, 2 hours queue having pre-buyed tickets
text:
The place maybe is nice to see, but the organization is totally nonsense.
They sell tickets for timed slot but when you come there you are put in the same, endless queue as anyone else.
The result is 2 hours queue under the sun, no shelter, no water, just wait and shut up.

title: A beautiful, badly managed monastery. If you go, be patient
text:
By organizing the purchase of tickets with a pre-established access time you should guarantee timed entrances but you will have to wait more than 2 hours under the sun. Not the entire monastery can be visited and they "give you a visit to the adjacent church". The staff is very rude. If you go, bring: water, a hat and a lot of patience
Too bad the monastery is very beautiful and nearby you can visit the beauty of Belem

title: Terrible treatment of tourists
text: Terrible tourist service. Absurd queue, without any information. Buy the ticket at a scheduled time and go to a common queue, in the sun, a complete mess. Don't go to this place. It's a humiliation for tourists

title: BAD SITE!
text:
Terrible organisation, arrogant, presumptuous and rude staff!
Queuing under the sun, about 90 minutes, we reported to the employees that a person could not stand under the sun due to personal problems and we asked if he could wait his turn in the shade
The answer was: "you need a medical certificate!"
Shame!
Be careful, timed tickets are put on sale, but then it turns out that the shift is exclusively for the faithful!
Absolutely, site to avoid!

title: TERRIBLE MANAGEMENT. Nice building.
text: The monastery is very beautiful but you can visit few rooms. And without a doubt THE WORST is the eternal queue you have to wait to get in. 1 hour and a half in line in the sun having bought the tickets online in advance. The management is ridiculous, shameful. Either they change that or I'm not sure if it's worth going.

title: SUPER LONG QUEUES
text: Queues of 1.5 hours, I cannot reserve times to enter, it is better to arrive and buy the ticket online not before or you will be surprised by the waiting time, the church is free, it is next door

title: Disappointed and sweaty.
text: We paid ‚Ç¨42 for the online tickets. There was not much to see for that. The whole shop has the same stonemason motifs over and over again. You can do a round on two levels and that's it. It takes 20 minutes to get through, but you've spent an hour or more cooking in the blazing sun in front of the entrance. Very disappointing.

title: Disappointment
text:
Disappointed by the management of tickets and waiting. We buy the tickets on the official online website at a certain time. Upon arrival, there was a tremendous queue to enter, assuming that this queue was for people who did not have an assigned time. To our amazement and disappointment, the waiting line is the same for everyone. It doesn't matter that you buy the ticket at a specific time because you have to wait in line anyway. We waited in the sun, without any shade, for an hour and a half.

Therefore, THE ALLOCATED TIME THAT APPEARS ON THE ONLINE TICKETS IS USELESS, AND YOU HAVE TO LINE UP LIKE EVERYONE. In our case, 1 HOUR AND A HALF.

As for the monastery, only the cloister is visible (and the church next door is free). It is beautiful, although it takes 20 - 30 minutes to see it and it has nothing spectacular and notable compared to other monasteries.

title: Terrible organization. I would not return nor recommend it
text:
Bad organization. Tickets purchased on the website with time selection. We entered 120 minutes later waiting in an eternal line and in full sun.
I would have enjoyed the interior if we hadn't arrived so tired.

title: Waste of time
text:
Said it would take an hour and it took 15 min after 1 hour in line‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs basically a courtyard. Look at the pictures and save yourself the money and time.

title: O mosteiro do desgosto
text: First is the long queues, with no fast tracking option. The visit is literally about 10 minutes going round. You not allowed to seat on the benches, not allowed to go in the patio, 90% of the rooms are closed and for 8.50 euros is a rip off. Not even the Buckingham palace have those restrictions. The only monument that I visit that‚Äôs not worth visiting. I don‚Äôt recommend and I hope the Portuguese authorities change this restrictions.

title: The Hieronymites monastery should be avoided
text:
We had purchased our tickets in advance.
We were lucky, the queue in the line only lasted about 25 minutes. The cloister is very pretty, however no explanation, the visit can be very quick. To go see the cathedral we are asked to queue again in the other direction, unacceptable. So another 15 min wait. This is absolutely not managed. The staff is only there to monitor the line. We really feel like stupid tourists. I advise you to take advantage of the outside for some photos and go to the maritime museum next door, it will be cheaper and more interesting.

title: online service does not meet schedules buy online
text:
Hello

disappointed with online service. there is absolutely no point in buying online and choosing a schedule. because he doesn't respect it. you arrive there and you queue.
we had booked for 9:30 am and we waited in the 1:30 am queue. our time being limited in the capital. a disgrace of service for an important and recognized monument. if you are taken by the time to avoid. the staff is already conditioned to answer you, they know it and ask you to make a complaint in a jaded tone.

title: See the pictures online and enjoy the holiday
text: Totally ridiculous with that queue, we didn't mind. Lots of other places to see and don't want to be laughed at and stand and cook in that sun. Then went for a walk around the area 5 * to it üòä

title: Deception when purchasing tickets on the official website with entry time selection
text:
Pathetic organization!
You buy tickets on the official website with a selection of entry time and they don't care! You have to wait in line, entering at the end 90 minutes later than the time selected and even indicated on your ticket.

title: Don't go there, avoid it
text:
Absolutely don't go there for 3 hours in a queue from 8 in the morning... a disaster, look at the attached photos... and then go in and discover that it's just a cloister on two floors... stop, no big deal.
Furthermore there is the church attached which is free compared to the monastery but you have to go out and queue again to get back under the sun for another few hours...absurd.
Don't book, there's no need, they don't keep booking timetables.
Don't go there at all, it's a waste of money... and that's not all... it's the time you waste under the sun...
We arrived at 8 in the morning and it opened at 9, and we entered at an absurd 11.30.

title: Ridiculously long line, time slots are not respected.
text: Although I had bought tickets online before 10 am and I got there well in time, I stood in line for 1.5 hours in the blazing sun before I got inside. What use is a ticket with a time slot if it is not looked at at all? Worthless. Perhaps they should be trained in Spain where time slots at well-known sights in Granada, Seville and Cordoba are respected/work well and regulate the crowds. Doesn't detract from the monastery, but access could be much better

title: It‚Äôs not worth 2 hours waiting under the Sun
text:
The cloister was really beautiful but it was not worth the waiting in Line for 2 hours under the sun.
We visited the place on the 15th of August: since it was an holiday, we bought the tickets online for 11.00 am.
It turns out that the time slot‚Äôs tickets was totally useless: there was only one waiting line (so long it reached the nautica museum) and you had to get in line even if you had tickets.
We waited 2 hours (literally 2 hours) and finally it was our turn.
It is possible to visit ONLY the cloister: it‚Äôs really beautiful but the visit took 20 minutes at maximum.
If you would like to visit even the church you have to do ANOTHER WAITING LINE!!!
That‚Äôs simply ridicolous.
Cherry on pie was that there wasn‚Äôt so many people inside so they could have let more tourists in!
One star for the terrible organization.
If you still want to visit the place, do not underestimate the sunlight: we were sunburt, so take with you water, sunscreen and an umbrella.

title: Terrible experience. Don't go there if you don't want to get sunstroke
text: It's absurd how a national monument can be so poorly and disorganized managed! And it's absurd how no one rebels! The queue to enter lasts more than 4 hours in a square under the sun! There is no point in purchasing tickets online, the scheduled time is not respected in any way, everyone has to queue at random, even those who have just purchased their ticket at the ticket office (completely empty, with no queue). Never seen such a situation, a lady felt ill. The staff were rude and unsympathetic. It's not worth going there. I advise you against it

title: What after paying in advance
text: We booked and paid, for a visit at 12.30 we have been queuing for over an hour and there will be an hour until we enter. Under the sun. Terrible setbozio

title: Logistics to be modified
text: The Monastery of Los Jeronimos is very beautiful, an unmissable visit. However, I give one star for the way in which the logistics are managed: in 2023 we waited 2 and a half hours in line in the August sun (compared to the visit which lasts about 30-45 minutes) and the line is not reported/controlled, guys rude people continued to enter the queue disrespectful of the people who had been waiting for hours. Even when we pointed out to them that the queue started elsewhere, they replied that they knew it but that they still did not move from the "earned" position. Aside from the sadness of certain encounters, it is absurd that so many hours have to be spent in line which could be used to the greater benefit of the city and its visitors.

title: Line
text: Disorganization is the key word unfortunately. The place is wonderful, the visit lasts about an hour (in which you will essentially see arcades) but you will most likely get there exhausted from the hours spent in line. To enter, in fact, you will not need to buy the ticket online with a pre-established time, here you will find the same queue for "with ticket" and "without ticket". So prepare yourself and arm yourself, above all with lots and lots of patience.

title: BAD
text:
BAD ORGANIZATION

There is no point in purchasing the ticket with a predefined time, limiting the number of entries, if the queue is random: first come, first served.
A tip: arrive at least half an hour before opening time and you will avoid hours of queuing.

title: Terrible queue at 40 degrees
text: A very long queue to enter at 40 degrees, waiting a long time despite arriving at 9:30...There were those who wanted to sneak in, so pay attention...They could organize it by time slots...the queue is deadly. Very nice interior.

title: Very beautiful but welcome to see again
text:
No flow management, 1 hour wait under the sun, no explanation on the site.
Accompanied by a disabled person with very reduced mobility, the reception was deplorable. Furthermore, she could only be accompanied by one person. No seat to sit on.
The site is very beautiful but the conditions need to be reviewed.

title: Family visit
text:
documenting in advance because there is no explanation or audio guide. The cultural content is weak and nothing wow
On the other hand, to visit the church, you have to queue again, in short, not serious. This deserves a reorganization of flows.
Contrary to what online sales operators sell, including the Lisboa card, there is no wire cutting, it's a scam

title: Shameful and catastrophic
text: After purchasing tickets on the monastery website for that day at 11:30 a.m., we arrived 15 minutes early. The queue was 3 hours long, the guard at the entrance told us. In fact, given the crowds waiting in full sun, there was enough time for 3 hours. We turned back! What is the point of purchasing tickets with a time slot in advance? This is pure theft!

title: Much better to see in Lisbon!
text: 2 hours in line for a building that is certainly very beautiful but which does not deserve this wait under the sun. The essential thing, in my opinion, is seen from the outside. The sculptures are incredible. Take the time to look at them, you will save time and money.

title: Bad luck
text: Unfortunately we have not been able to access the Monastery. We bought the Lisbon card and we couldn't enter due to WYD restrictions that, even knowing what was going to happen, no one in Lisbon warned in time. Three days after the papal arrival we tried to go and seeing a line in the sun lasting more than 2 hours made us give up. Like this, there are many other examples of how Lisbon has ‚Äúturned its attention‚Äù to WYD2023 and has neglected tourists who, like us, I don't think will return to the Portuguese capital for a long time. Bad management and little honesty.

title: Move on, really.
text: Simply a scam! 1h10 wait from the opening, the staff is not friendly, groups of 50 people walk past you. For a 15 min visit, 2 tombs, 1 empty refectory without explanation, no access to the church, in short for 10 euros for two, move on, go instead to the electricity museum 200 m away which is 1000 x more interesting and motivating.

title: Forf√¶rdelig lang k√∏ trods forh√•ndsk√∏bt billet. Smuk klosterg√•rd
text:
Ventede i k√∏ i en time trods forh√•ndsk√∏bt billet Virkede h√•bl√∏st arrogant og ineffektivt at lade s√• mange mennesker vente i over 30 graders bagende sol, n√•r der var masser af plads da vi f√∏rst kom ind.
Selve klosterg√•rden var meget smuk, men vi var dybt skuffede over, at s√• lang ventetid kun b√∏d p√• selve g√•rden. Meget lidt information.
Vil frar√•de alle der rejser i h√∏js√¶son den oplevelse

title: Waste of time and money
text:
Don't waste your money or time. We paid to "skip the queue" for a slot, waited over an hour in the blistering sun just to walk around for 15mins. That's it, 5-10 mins and it isn't worth ¬£10.

I strongly advise not booking ahead. Go there, check the queue, question if you want to pay the fee

The queue took far too long to process

title: Not worth the time!
text: Most of the monastery is closed to the public. The part you can see only takes about 10 to 15 minutes and there is very little to it. Given that the line to get in is 30 to 90 minutes it is a total waste of time to go see this.. picture of another fountain

title: S√≥ conseguir ver o exterior, tamanha fila na entrada.
text: O exterior do mosteiro √© muito lindo, mas n√£o consegui entrar, na verdade nem tentei, pois a fila √© desanimadora. Certamente o visitante fica em p√© no minimo 1,5h para entrar, Lament√°vel!

title: L‚Äôattente ne vaut pas le coup
text:
Attente d‚Äôune heure et demi en plein soleil, les tickets achet√©s en ligne ne sont pas des coupes files.
Visite termin√©e en 15 minutes pour un billet √† 10‚Ç¨
Conditions d‚Äôacc√®s d√©sastreuses, des vendeurs essayent de vous vendre de l‚Äôeau, des lunettes et des casquettes pendant votre supplice.
Fuyez

title: Tanta fila sotto il sole x vedere poco
text: Scusate ma x un italiano non ne vale la pena. Avevamo biglietti x le 9:30 il primo ingresso possibile. Arriviamo in uber in orario perch√© il sito √® fuori mano e alle 9:30 gi√† cera fila. Dopo un ora entriamo e scopriamo che la fila con il biglietto √® solo x il chiostro; se vuoi vedere la chiesa che √® nello stesso complesso, ti fanno uscire fuori e ti chiedono di metterti di nuovo in fila perch√© l ingresso x la chiesa √® gratuito e devi farti un altra ora di coda in ina fila dedicata: noi delusi siamo andati via dopo aver visto il chiostro. Bello ma x la fila fatta a saperlo me lo sarei risparmiato. Organizzazione e comunicazione pessima

title: Geen ticket met tijdslot boeken
text:
Geen ticket vooraf boeken! Het geboekte tijdslot kennen ze niet en je staat als nog in de lange rij.
Tip: ga in de namiddag, dan is de rij korter.

title: No respect from staff
text:
Deplorable customer service.
We Asked where to buy tickets and were grunted at to join the queue. One hour later in roasting summer sun we reached the end of the queue, we were screeched at for having no tickets and refused help or holding our position in the queue while we fixed the problem.
We refused to queue again.
Very disappointed.

title: Worst experience in Lisbon and only Balem tower is somehow compatible to how bag one tourist attraction could be.
text: This is the biggest tourist trap I experienced in Lisbon. We got the Lisbon card that supposed to include fast track. It actually didn't. We waited on the sun for almos a hour and when we got inside we saw nothing. They alow to to walk only on the outside and there is nothing realy nothing to see there. Better save your money and go to see the Lisbon catedral.

title: Terrible experience at Jeronimos Monastery - avoid if you can
text: I would give this site 0 stars if I could. This would be regarding management and planning for entrance. We bought timed tickets online for 10:00 am. Got there at 10:15 am only to be told that it doesn't matter that we have timed tickets!!, we need to queue with all the other people some of whom didn't have tickets. What is the point of selling timed tickets and not taking them into consideration??? Lines were extremely long, in the full sun with temperatures getting over 30C. I estimated maybe 2 hours of wait. We didn't stay. There were 2 lines: 1 for regular people and 1 for groups. Of course, the groups were many and they also had to queue. They might have had priority. Also I heard the security people talking very rudely with the groups to the point that the guide had to intervene. Really, this is how Portugal treats their visitors??? I would avoid this place till they review their management.

title: Disorganizzazione allo stato puro
text: Avevamo prenotato il biglietto sia con giorno e orario , ma al nostro arrivo non era possibile visitarlo poich√© c‚Äôera una manifestazione ( non segnalato al momento della nostra prenotazione ) . Abbiamo dovuto attendere il pomeriggio e fare una fila interminabile sotto il sole cocente ( cosa che avviene regolarmente) , oltretutto il personale e‚Äô abbastanza scorbutico ( nonostante i grossi disagi creato dalla disorganizzazione) . Il tempo speso e il costo del biglietto non vale assolutamente la visita , ci sono luoghi decisamente pi√π meritevoli a Lisbona .

title: Good site, but you better think twice before going. On line time slot reservations are NOT honored!
text:
Great place and beautiful architecture but you better consider the extremely disorganized and chaotic entrance before you go. No point on reserving a time entry, you have to make the line anyway, online time slots are NOT honored. The line can be up to 2 hours (in the full sun) and the personnel are very rude and unprofessional. The long line outside makes no sense, there is plenty of space inside and the building is big enough to allow more people without crowding it. This facility is managed by "Patrimonio Cultural" (state agency) and that explains it all...
My personal advise is that any line longer than 20 minutes (specially in rough weather conditions) is NOT worth it.
However you should check the church next to it (Santa Maria de Belem), the entrance is free (restricted during Mass times) and it is as beautiful inside as it is outside. You might want to check the explanation posted on the right side of the entrance, it provides all you need to know about the decoration and details of the door entrance.

title: disorganizzazione
text:
Avevo da tempo desiderato di visitare il Monastero ma ahim√® il desiderio non si √® avverato a causa della pessima organizzazione. Avevo prenotato la visita con scelta non solo del giorno ma anche dell'ora, con la certezza di accedere in quell'orario, come succede in qualsiasi altro sito.
Invece devi metterti in coda come gli altri che non hanno nessuna prenotazione, sotto un sole cocente e con tempi di attesa lunghissimi col risultato che, gran parte della gente rinuncia, pur avendo gi√† pagato.
Sar√† veramente disorganizzazione?

title: P√©sima experiencia de ingreso
text: Llegamos con 34 grados, entradas compradas online... y sin embargo nos sorprendio encontrar una linea de unos 150mts de personas...Necesitabamos espeear minimo hora y media para ingresar. De nada serv√≠a tener los tickets. P√©simo el sistema. Nunca llegamos a entrar ya q lastimosamente no teniamos disponible ese tiempo para esperar.

title: Batiment exceptionnel
text: Tickets online de 10 eurs par personne pour 10h30. Arriv√©e 9h50 d√©j√† une file assez cons√©quente. Nos billets ne permettent un passage r√©serv√©. Entr√©e 11h10 . Temps d attente en plein soleil assez long. Visite +ou- 1h . Endroit exceptionnel qu il faut voir ! Mais tr√®s mauvaise organisation des entr√©es avec les groupes qui passent avant et si vous voulez voir la m√™me chose qu eux il faut refaire la file. Beaucoup de critiques dans la file d attente qui √©taient justifi√©es car plein soleil et √ßa n' avan√ßait pas . Donc pour moi a √©viter si vous n' √™tes pas en groupe ! Les horaires sur le site de r√©servation online compl√®tement inutile puisque vous devez faire la file ! Perte de temps importante et a d√©conseiller pour les personnes ag√©es. File d attente jusqu au parking des bus .

title: Don't believe the hype
text: Not worthwhile the long waiting line (2hrs) in the hot sun or the price (10euro). Basically the insight court of the monastery, walking the upstairs and downstairs corridors, no exhibits, no story or indications, not audio guide. The pace is slow and the organization of the site lacks a lot. To spend at most 1 hr inside it is not worth the 2hr queing

title: Seems to be a nice place
text: Even if you book a slot you won‚Äòt get into the monastery if you are not prepared to stand in line for- in our case- 2hrs. As it was very hot and we didn‚Äòt want to go through this ordeal we forfeited our tickets. At least from the outside the place is beautiful

title: Attente interminable pour peu de choses √† l‚Äôarriv√©e
text:
Franchement, c‚Äôest une √©preuve.
Vous achetez des tickets sur le Net, coupe-file, peut-on lire.
En fait, vous ne coupez pas du tout √† la file d‚Äôattente !
Plus d‚Äôune heure en plein soleil, je n‚Äôose imaginer ce que ce serait en √©t√©‚Ä¶
L‚Äôarchitecture est, certes grandiose, mais la d√©coration est plut√¥t charg√©e, voire lourde‚Ä¶
La visite est vite faite, vous d√©ambulez autour d‚Äôune belle cour int√©rieure, prenez quelques photos et puis c‚Äôest tout.
L‚Äôacc√®s √† l‚Äô√©glise est gratuit.
Mais il faut refaire la queue‚Ä¶
On a laiss√© tomber.
Allez plut√¥t vous goinfrer de pasteis de Belem !

title: Horrible guard on entrance
text: Pretty building but terrible experience with the round-faced guard working on the entrance on 3 June 2023 between 5-5.30pm. Having rushed to get there in time, he was lying to tourists that it closed at 5 (when actually last entrance 5.30 for 6pm closing). He then lied about the ticket office being closed and ages away. I then started buying a ticket online as not yet 5.30 and he taunted me saying I would never manage to buy in time and even if it was 5.30 he wouldn't let me in (5.29 latest). Bizarre behaviour, as if he enjoyed turning away tourists and going on a weird power trip. Luckily I bought the ticket before 5.30 and another guard let me through, but unfortunately other tourists left disappointed when he first lied about it being closed. Inside was pretty but not loads to see (so can do it in far less than half an hr). Overall an unpleasant experience.

title: Disappointing monastery waiting time!
text: Very disappointing day at Belem. Very Very Long queues even at 9.30/10am and also even if you have purchased tickets in advance it seems to make no difference. Be prepared to stand in the queue and in the heat. We will come in winter to get in as otherwise just not worth it. We went to beautiful tropical gardens behind the famous custard tart shop just to escape the crowds. Not worth spoiling holiday for these crazy queues.

title: Online Tickets sind ein Schwindel
text:
Was f√ºr ein Schwindel !
Es werden Zeittickets verkauft. Allerdings so viele dass trotzdem 1h Schlangestehen notwendig ist. Das Personal interessieren die Zeitfenster gar nicht. Genauso kann man Vorort Tickets kaufen, das macht keinen Unterschied. F√ºr mich ist das ein Betrug weil man dem online K√§ufer vormacht er m√ºsse p√ºnktlich da sein und sich so das Anstehen sparen.

title: Delusione totale
text: Apertura 9:30... peccato che pur essendo tra i primi fino alle 10:30 fermi on lisbona card perch√© fan passare davanti tutti i gruppi... visto che di chiese ce ne sono tante a questo mondo, pagare 10 euro per vedere per pi√π tempo l'entrata che gli interni di questa penso sia assolutamente evitabile....

title: Inexcusable lines, avoid
text: This was the only attraction I declined to see in Lisbon, and I don't regret it. Twice within a week, I ventured here and twice the lines were insanely long, despite a system of timed tickets. We're talking 60-90 minutes baking under the sun, according to live postings on social media. Forget it. A vacation is about relaxing, not working. Yes, the monastery exterior is beautiful from the outside. But I can't speak about the interior. If you go to Belem, check out the nearby contemporary art museum, the explorers' monument and the Tower instead, all within walking distance. Whoever runs the monastery must overhaul its ticketing and queuing system, because now it's losing visitors like me.

title: Ruined by mass tourism
text:
Looks nice from the outside, but it has been destroyed by mass tourism. Swathes and swathes of tourists descend on it and the queues are astronomical. You can't visit without spending hours and hours stood in a queue and it is not worth it.
In the other end of the monastery is the maritime museum, it is better to go in that, you actually get to go in some of the monastery buildings and there was no wait.

title: Quelle honte
text:
Une queue interminable alors que nous avions pris le soin de prendre nos billets sur internet avec un slot horaire pr√©cis. La r√©ponse qui m‚Äôa √©t√© donn√©e par le gardien est que l‚Äôhoraire sur le billet est √† titre indicatif. M√™me pas le courage d‚Äôassumer leur incomp√©tence dans la gestion d‚Äôune file d‚Äôattente. Et quand on voit les personnes √¢g√©es qui attendent sous le soleil‚Ä¶. C‚Äôest juste inadmissible vu le type de monument!!
A titre d‚Äôinformation, les files d‚Äôattente au palais de Pe√±a √† Sintra sont √©galement organis√©es par cr√©neaux horaires, mais avec des pancartes bien visibles derri√®res lesquelles chacun attend en fonction de son horaire de visite.
Le clo√Ætre vaut le coup, mais bon‚Ä¶. Nous avons largement pr√©f√©r√© l‚Äô√©glise, pour laquelle il faut ressortir et refaire une seconde queue mais beaucoup plus rapide cette derni√®re.

title: Horrible logistics
text: Be forewarned that although you reserve tickets for a certain time, tour groups get priority, and if there are many groups at the time you arrive you may wait in line well past the time on your reservation. There is no signage and It is hard to find anyone to provide information about the different lines, and why some go very slowly. We only found out what was going on by asking a lot of people until we found someone who knew. Make sure you are in the correct line and be prepared for what can be a long wait if you indeed want to go in. None of the people working for the Monastary seem to care how frustrating this can be for visitors

title: Une honte dans la gestion des queues et les passe droits
text:
Une heure de queue apr√®s avoir acheter le billet sur internet pour le clo√Ætre et voir d√©filer tous les groupes. Puis apr√®s la visite du clo√Ætre on est oblig√© de refaire la queue pour visiter l‚Äô√©glise
On se moque de nous une honte

title: Te lang wachten vs tijd binnen
text:
aanrader om tickets op voorhand te kopen.
Zelfs dan nog lang aanschuiven‚Ä¶ dus wees vroeg.
Bezoek zelf is in vergelijking met aanschuiven kort, persoonlijk niet in evenwicht. Heb je minder tijd bezoek dan enkel de kerk (is gratis) en
Minder lang aanschuiven

title: terrible staff
text:
it is nice inside but terrible staff behaviour..
bought tickets online but waited in the line with all others.
make sure you know in whitch line you are standing because there are three of them

title: P√©sima organizaci√≥n. Nunca vi algo asi
text: El monasterio es muy bonito pero lo empalidece la p√©sima organizaci√≥n. Para la entrada. Filas de cuadras, lentitud exasperante, horas de espera. Nunca vi algo as√≠. Ni a prop√≥sito se puede hacer peor.

title: If your hobby is queuing you will love it
text:
In an unusually warm April (30¬∞) this is the worst place to visit.
Not because it is unattractive but because you can't visit without queuing for 2 hours.
Yes you read it right... TWO hours.
We bought Lisboa cards which gave us "skip the queue" admission.
The 2 hour queue was for the "skip the queue" entry by the way....
I don't normally review places I've not been into but I felt I had to because the Lisboa card isn't worth the money.
Lisbon is a popular cruise ship stopover now.
Two in daily during our city break, disgorging up to 10,000 visitors at a time.
Copy and paste this review for...
Torre do Belem
Both Elevadores
E28 tram

title: Trotz Ticket stundenlanges Warten. Besser nicht.
text: Eigentlich ein Topziel in Lissabon. Trotz Ticket muss man stundenlang in der Sonne warten. Auch schon am fr√ºhen Morgen, wenn die Sonne schon √ºber 25 C erreicht hat. Kein Schatten

title: Trop d'attente pour un petit tour de clo√Ætre
text: Bien s√ªr c'est magnifique maintenant faire 1h30 de queue en plein soleil pour faire 20 mn de clo√Ætre c'est pour moi un mauvais compromis. Une fois sortis du clo√Ætre il faut refaire la queue pour aller dans l'√©glise...j'ai donc l√¢ch√© l'affaire.

title: Laaange Warteschlange trotz Lisboacard Gratiseintritt
text: Leider haben wir es nicht hinein geschafft!!! Achtung! Trotz Lisboacard/Gratiseintritt unendlich lange Wartezeit in der prallen Sonne!!!

title: Not worth the excruciating wait.
text: Terrible wait outside - over an hour with prosthesis knee and husband with bad feet and walking stick. Nowhere to sit. No sign to ticket office so could have queued for nothing!!!! Luckily people in queue told us. No advantage getting online ticket as same queue. Must be a bit of a shock to find they get visitors as they are not in the least prepared!!!

title: Personnel tr√®s d√©sagr√©able √† la limite de la politesse
text:
Un lieu vraiment tr√®s beau mais un personnel absolument horrible qui abuse de son pouvoir. Nous faisons la queue 1 h pour rentrer dans le monast√®re. Puis au moment de rentrer dans la chapelle on nous demande de refaire la queue a autre endroit ( de fa√ßon tr√®s d√©sagr√©able) alors 30 personnes devant nous viennent de rentrer.
Incompr√©hensible et surtout tr√®s tr√®s d√©sagr√©able !!!

title: Entry Process is Ridiculous
text:
My husband and I visited the Monastery on Tuesday, March 28. I bought the tickets online from the Patrimonio Cultural (Directorate General for Cultural Heritage) government site. The site says they are responsible for the direct management of 26 monuments and museums, for which they provide information and sell tickets. One of those sites is the Jeronimos Monastery. I assumed that when the site said the Monastery requires a date and time booking, and then does indeed require you to pick both before you can buy a ticket, that it was legitimate. When we arrived at the site, however, and I asked staff (3 of them, at two different locations) where we should line up for access with a timed ticket, it was all they could do to keep to a smirk and not actually laugh outright at me. I was told that tickets are sold on many sites and none of them is any different from any other. They did not even look at my ticket - we were just told to get in line with everyone else. I have seen people mention in other reviews that they didn't get in until well past the time they signed up for, so I would like to make it clear that in our case, the problem wasn't just that they were running late, the problem was that they were not acknowledging that timed entry for individuals existed at all. I don't know if this is a problem with the setup/wording of the website - perhaps they mean to say that groups have to have timed entry but it doesn't apply to individuals? But in that case, why do individuals still have to pick an exact time for entry, or allowed to buy tickets at all? And why are those in charge of entry at the actual Monastery not trained with an appropriate response for all those who arrive with expectations?

Anyway, we chose to wait - an hour and half - to go into the Monastery. The part that you get to see is very limited and although the architecture is undeniably beautiful, even taking our time to admire it and take photos, we were only there for 30 minutes. I would suggest not lining up for more than half an hour for entry - there are many other historic buildings to see in the Lisbon area that also have beautiful architecture.

title: DECEPCI√ìN MAY√öSCULA.
text: Lo primero que debes tener en cuenta al ir a visitar el "Monasterio de los Jer√≥nimos" es que no vas a visitar el Monasterio, y eso ya empieza mal. Lo √∫nico que se visita es el claustro del Monasterio y no entras en ninguna estancia salvo que vayas al servicio. Lo segundo es que arquitect√≥nicamente es bonito, claro, como todos, pero vamos, en Espa√±a hay cientos como este o mejores. Y lo tercero, Lisboa, ah√≠ la tienes, est√° masificada de turismo y nosotros estuvimos esperando dos horas de reloj para una visita de apenas 30 minutos, todo ello sin reparar en el precio, que NADA en Portugal a nivel tur√≠stico es barato. Menci√≥n especial con el personal de seguridad y de atenci√≥n al p√∫blico, el trato deja mucho que desear. Ya he cumplido y no me volver√°n a ver.

title: Pure oplichting
text: Tickets online gekocht voor 13h00. We komen exact om 13h00 toe waar een arrogant mannetje in een uniform ons duidelijk maakt dat we netjes achteraan de rij mogen aansluiten om pas een uur later binnen te kunnen. Waarom een website maken (overigens voor het grootste deel enkel in portugees) met slots per half uur als je je er toch geen fluit van aantrekt. Als excuus en vergoelijking voert dat sujet dan nog aan dat er al mensen in de rij staan met tickets om om 10h30 binnen te gaan. Alsof dat het beter zou maken ???

title: Pas pu rentrer
text: D√©sol√© par avance. Mais il y a un site, pour acheter des places en avance, et booker une date ainsi qu'un cr√©neau horaire. √áa ne sert √† rien. Queue √©norme devant le monast√®re. De une a deux heure je dirais. (on a tent√© d'attendre 30mn, on a pas fait 1/4 de la file) on ne pouvais pas casser notre programme de la journ√©e on a donc pas pu acc√©der au monast√®re. Bravo √† ceux qui on fait la queue, tant pis pour mes 10balles...

title: Closed early without giving notice, after we paid full priced ticket. Didn‚Äôt get to see the church.
text: Closed early without giving notice after we paid full priced ticket. Didn‚Äôt get to see the church. Very poor form. Disappointing.

title: Mala Atenci√≥n en el monasterio de los ger√≥nimos
text:
Una pena que este lugar tan maravilloso est√© tan mal administrado. Tickets a las13:00hrs y no se puede entrar hasta las 14:30. Entre medio el personal de seguridad introduce gente en la fila (30 personas) , que se saltan el tiempo de espera.
Muy triste, no es para el est√°ndar de turismo europeo.

title: La coda non giustifica la visita
text: Dopo un ora di coda nonostante i biglietti comprati online siamo riusciti ad entrare. L'interno √® effettivamente molto bello ma la visita non dura pi√π di 20-30 minuti. Quindi ho avete molto tempo da perdere o non ne vale la pena. In aggiunta il costo del biglietto non ti d√† diritto all'ingresso della chiesa tagliando la coda che anche qui √® dell'ordine delle ore.

title: Didn‚Äôt got inside, cause of organization
text:
We got in day when was first Sunday of month and it was free. We didn‚Äôt need this entrance for free, but we were there and wanted to look inside.

Please put some sign in website if it is for free then as well aware to take the ticket where written archeology museum, otherewise like we and others who were standing in the queue 1,5 h and even ask before the security is it really for free - yes! We continue to stand! After 1,5 h in the queue - sorry we and othere just turn away not to visit this important place.
Please put some signs or signs on the queue to avoid such experience for others!

title: Umsonst hingefahren
text: Beeindruckend, zumindest von au√üen. Aufgrund der noch beeindruckenderen Warteschlange haben wir das Innere nicht besichtigt. Schade.

title: Not worth it!!!
text: My daughter and I had timed tickets for 11:00 am on March 28, 2023. We had to wait in line for an hour and 40 minutes passed our allotted time to go in. We were only inside for about 20 minutes. So not worth it!!! Then came out and waited in line for the chapel for about 10 minutes. The chapel is free and has a short line so I recommend just going there.

title: Overrated‚Ä¶.
text:
Presumably one of the must-see places, UN World Heritage site. In reality, grandiose architecture but empty inside. No connection or stories with who used to live here.
Even with an online ticket for a time slot, be prepared to wait in line a long time (45 min or more on this Wednesday morning). The neighboring church with Vasco da Gama‚Äôs tomb is free but there is another line to get in. And it‚Äôs kind of dark, no connection spiritually or otherwise.

title: Lovely building but not worth a 50 minute wait to get in.
text: Yes the monastery is a very beautiful building but when you have to wait for 50 minutes to get in you start to question if you really want to go.We finally got in and spent out 30 minutes inside nothing much really to see came out more queues for the church so decided to go home via the jam packed trams.

title: Not a "must see"
text: It is admittedly an incredible building. It is beautiful and it is huge... but as others have said, you stand in line for a very long time to get in. And you are literally in there for 15 minutes. All you see are The Cloisters and there is very little in the way of written information. And then once you leave The Cloisters there is another big long line to see the cathedral. We did not even bother with that. In my mind this was a tourist trap and kind of a waste of time

title: WARNING!!!!
text:
Warning: unless you buy an advance ticket on line, you will need to go through three lines, one to get your ticket, one to enter the monestary and one to enter the church. Each can take from 30 minutes to an hour. The ticket line is separate from the monestary line and located in the archaeological museum some distance away.

There are no timed entry except for authorized groups between 9:30 and 10:30.

Suggestion: buy ticket in advance and show up near closing to avoid long wait for an attraction worth about 45 minutes.

title: D√©cevant
text:
Le monast√®re est tr√®s beau mais nous ne pouvons visiter que la grande cour centrale et ses balcons sur 2 √©tages, une visite d'√† peine 20 √† 30mn.

La file d'attente est 3 fois plus longue que la visite.

R√©server un cr√©neau horaire sur Internet √† l'avance ne sert √† rien, il n'y a qu'une seule file d'attente pour tout le monde, avec ou sans billets.

Il est possible de visiter l'√©glise avec le m√™me billet, mais il faut faire de nouveau la queue.

Pour 10eur, √ßa ne vaut pas le coup.

title: Ticket nonsense
text: Queued for 40 minutes expecting to be able to buy a ticket onsite. Turns out the ticket office is in the Archaeological Museum next door, no signage anywhere to tell you this apart from a tiny a4 piece of paper. Gave up.

title: Grande d√©ception
text:
Autant d‚Äôattente pour si peu. Inclus dans la Lisboa Card, j‚Äôaurais √©t√© particuli√®rement d√©√ßu si j‚Äôavais pay√© des billets‚Ä¶
Apr√®s la courte visite du clo√Ætre (parce qu‚Äôil n‚Äôy a pas vraiment rien d‚Äôautre ouvert √† la visite), nous aurions d√ª refaire √† nouveau une autre file pour visiter l‚Äô√©glise, ce que nous n‚Äôavons pas fait - assez de temps perdu.
Je ne comprends pas la sur√©valuation de cette visite‚Ä¶

title: Urlaub in der Warteschlange
text: Selbst in der Nebensaison unfassbar lange Wartezeiten. Null Info vom Personal, wie lange die ungef√§hre Wartezeit betr√§gt.

title: Terrible queuing system so expect to lose a chunk of your day
text:
We booked online and hence expected a queue jump. However, you‚Äôre forced to wait in a huge queue for 1 hour plus. There‚Äôs no reason for this, they control the number of people entering but it‚Äôs a huge place and it was barely crowded. You‚Äôre then done within 20-30 mins as there isn‚Äôt much to see.

If you can go when the queue is tiny, it‚Äôs worth it. If not, unfortunately they haven‚Äôt entered the 21st century and force you to queue for a huge amount of time. What‚Äôs worse is when you book online you have to choose an entry time which is helpful to plan your day around. Yet, this is meaningless when you turn up, you‚Äôll enter 1-1.5 hours after that time so good luck.

title: √â realmente interessante pra vc?
text: N√£o v√° ao local ‚Äúporque todo mundo vai‚Äù. Pesquise antes para ver se faz sentido pra vc. Eu n√£o fiz isso e n√£o tive uma boa experi√™ncia - por isso posso te dar este conselho.

title: Horr√≠vel
text: Equipe de seguran√ßa na fila extremamente despreparada, com n√≠tidos problemas de nervos, gritando e debochando de crian√ßas somente pq passaram por baixo das fitas que fazem demarca√ß√£o das filas sendo que n√£o havia nenhuma pessoa na fila! NENHUMA pessoa! √âramos os pr√≥ximos a entrar na Igreja. Agress√£o verbal e olhares de amea√ßa a menores de idade! Sugiro fazerem reciclagem com a equipe nitidamente despreparada! N√£o recomendo essa atra√ß√£o a nenhuma pessoa que v√° a Portugal!

title: Waste of money. The church is for FREE
text:
Don‚Äôt pay the 10‚Ç¨!! That‚Äôs just to visit a patio.
The church is the most beautiful building and you can get in for FREE.
A poor experience for the money.

The 10‚Ç¨ is just to see the patio and a hallway.
Granted, they have a nice architecture, but nothing extraordinary.

The staff is mostly rude and they try to ignore any questions to make you pay the visit.
It‚Äôs just not worth the money.

Pity, with a friendlier staff and a fee according to the sights I‚Äôd walked out with a different experience.

title: Andate presto!
text:
Se siete a Lisbona, andateci, perch√® √® bello, ma preparatevi a una coda infinita (anche con la Lisboa card). Diciamo almeno 1h di coda e 40' di visita.
Poi dovrete rifare la coda per visitare la chiesa (gratis). Organizzazione Filini...

title: Very limited display
text: The Carmo has a historical significance for the Portugese and I respect it. But the display is rather dull, with a small number of artifacts to examine if compared to other museums, even small ones. There's a movie about the Carmo, but it is simply not enough. After 30 minutes we were done. Maybe it's better to visit with a guide.

title: there are better places to learn more about Lisbon and roman times.
text:
I visited the Carmo Archaeological Museum during a week long visit to Lisbon.

The museum consists of the church nave, open to the sky, and a few rooms of archaeological items - church art and carvings, some new world artifacts, and some roman era artifacts. I found the place ok, but it didn't have the depth of collection of other museums, nor was it good at helping tell the story of the artifacts.

I much preferred the Museu da Lisboa in Campo Grande (great collection, nice space), and Museu do Teatro Romano. For roman history, the Nucleo Arqueologico da Rua dos Correiros (underneath Millennium BCP's offices) told a much better story about life in Lisbon in the past during their short guided tour, and the similar ruins visible on the ground floor of Casa dos Bicos were nice once I understood the story from Nucleo Arqueologico about garam production in Lisbon during the roman era.

title: You don't miss much
text:
I consider that it is not an essential place to see in Lisbon. You don't miss too much.

There are no detailed explanations of the different archaeological remains (from different periods) that appear, only the name. It consists of 4 small rooms, one of them being a room where they display an explanatory video (it is original) of the history of the monument.

What is striking is the nonexistence of the roof and the remains that remain.

The entrance fee is ‚Ç¨5 (adults), and the duration of the visit is personal, but in my case, approximately 20-30 minutes.

title: Total waste of 6 minutes and ‚Ç¨10
text:
Thought this place would be interesting, paid ‚Ç¨5 each to get inside to find most of it was covered in scaffold and cladding. We stayed all of 6 minutes and left laughing at the farce of it all. We have monuments at home that are far more interesting than this and are normally free to get into. It‚Äôs really not worth it.
Love wandering around Lisbon, it is a really interesting city, we have travelled to a lot of places and major cities, not all reviewed on here and I can honestly say we have never been anywhere with as many unorganised queues as Lisbon. Even Venice wasn‚Äôt this bad!

title: Very disappointing
text:
Only reproductions (poorly proportioned), the few comments that "explain" the works are not enough to make it a must in my opinion.
13‚Ç¨ is far too expensive for a not at all immersive experience. After some research on the Internet, these "museums" are not approved at all by the artist, as are reproductions that are made without authorization. Slot machines ... In short very disappointing.

title: Robbing Banksy
text: This should be called the anti-Banksy museum as it's contradicting everything he stands for. It is unoriginal and commercialised. A copy of Christ with Shopping Bags is there, ironically near the gift shop selling whatnots probably from sweatshops. I think it's shockingly disrespectful to the artist.

title: Care.
text: I went to school and the care was terrible. The people who visited us are super bad-humored and poorly educated. I do not recommend making the visit with a guide there is more preference of solo with people so it is better alone than poorly accompanied.

title: Just one room
text: It was interesting but it is literally 1 room with portraits of Portugal's presidents around the sides and an assortment of random gifts received on state visits.

title: What a beautiful museum!Shame the Guide
text: The museum is valuable and so is the setting. Beautiful rooms, beautiful objects. A real shame that the Guide (guided tours only) is absolutely not up to scratch: it provides basic, essential explanations and, what is worse, does not give visitors time to see. He seems in a great hurry to send them away!

title: There‚Äôs nothing to see.
text: Nothing to see here - a few rooms with baskets and nothing else. No ‚Äúfolk art‚Äù at all. I am sure that there are many types of Portuguese folk arts that could be displayed but nothing here.

title: Your cup of tea
text: Whatever is in exhibit, it is not everyone's cup of tea. If it is, you will like it. If it is not, not worth visiting.

title: The archaeological area is modest
text: On the southern slopes of Castle Hill, just 50 meters north of the cathedral's apse, are the remains of a 1st-century Roman theatre. The archaeological area, protected by a roof, is freely visible from above but the remains are very few and if there were not a large panel with the design of the steps, they could hardly be identified as a theatre. Maybe for the locals it has its importance but we Italians are used to many other testimonies of Roman civilization. For those who still want to delve deeper into the site (by paying a modest ticket: three euros which drops to half if you are over 65), the museum also has an exhibition section (entrance on the other side of the road from the archaeological area, in two seventeenth-eighteenth century buildings appropriately adapted to the new museum role and with a view of the Tagus) where stone pieces from the theater are exhibited but also other archaeological evidence from different periods, even prior to that of the theatre, such as the collection of ceramics covering the period from the 4th century BC to the 17th century.
The museum is a dry because there is nothing to do for the kids has history but I already get to school to learn we didn't have any guide for us to show

title: Oh well
text: The museum starts off quite interestingly with modern aspects but quickly falls back into the last century. The exhibition is interesting but presented very carelessly. The hall with the boats looks much more interesting in photos than they actually are.

title: Disappointed
text:
Yesterday, first Sunday of March, information on the fact that the museum is free and that is not true!!! Many disappointed people who leave... Updating the information on the internet would be
more than desirable!!! It would be free at 2 p.m., watch out for the clock!!! Really sad!!

title: Verstaubt und aus der Zeit gefallen
text: Ein Museum mit v√∂llig veraltetem Konzept, das die Kolonialgeschichte verharmlost und unkritisch Heldenverehrung betreibt.

title: What a lack of interest, what a waste of time‚Ä¶
text:
No interest
Revolutionary package commonplaces
Pure waste of time
Portugal has a history, and this ‚Äúmuseum‚Äù insults that history

title: Rude staff
text: I do not Recommendation the highly rude personal visit and in addition the visit is not striking. AWFUL. With all the museums available....better go to other

title: N√£o visitar
